div.p: Here is the complete documentation for 84000 TEI Documents. In the body there is a list of all the specifications for element, model classes, attribute classes, macros, and datatypes. The back matter contains first a set of guidelines for our own markup editors showing the process for the markup stage of our texts, which is then followed by some other appendices with further topics and instructions for markup editors. All of these sections are accessible through links in the table of contents.

NOTE FOR UPDATING THE SCHEMA: This ODD contains some content models that are written directly with RELAX NG in order to shape and restrict the form for published 84000 texts. If these need to be updated in the ODD, these content models, which outline the whole of the text are primarily to be found in the elementSpecs for the teiHeader, front, body, and back elementsSome RELAX NG content models are also defined in the a few macroSpec elements that are pointed to from within the content models of these four mentioned elementSpecs. All the the macroSpecs have been placed at the beginning of the ODD's XML after the moduleRefs and classSpecs, these are then followed by the elementSpecs. See Appendix: for more details on proceedures for updating the schema.

remarks.p: body (text body) contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter. So in an 84000 TEI encoded document, the body contains the whole translated text. It does not material written by the translator or editors, but just the original text in translation. It is part of the text, coming after front and before back. The body section opens approximately the same way in every document. The front closing tag precedes the body opening tag. That is followed by the div tag with the type attribute containing the "translation" value. This is followed by the head elements, with type values first of "translation" and then "titleMain", and then "titleHon" as shown below. After this comes the chapter or section div's, and so on. Even if there is no chapter division in the body of the translated text, there is minimally one section or chapter div, containing then the whole of the translation, and closing before the "colophon". Structurally the colophon section is equivalent to a chapter, and colophon is a value of a type attribute of a div element. The colophon div closes and then comes the closing div tag of the translation, and then the closing body tag.

remarks.p: div (text division) contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text. All three subsections of the Front are designated by a div tag, which includes a type attribute that holds a value reflecting which subsection it is, for example: div type="acknowledgment". Likewise the body has a div tag marking the translation, and within the translation, at least two div's, making the main part of the translation and the colophon. Any further subdivisions of the translation, into chapters or sections require additional div tags. All of the tags also contain the type attribute and translation, chapter, section or colophon values. This works the same way for the back section, with four div tags, at least. Each again has the type attribute and values of notes, listBibl (within listBible at least one div with type section) and glossary.
Note that a prologue or colophon section should be marked as such, e.g., type="prologue" and not be labeled as "section".

Because of the particularities of electronic publishing, P5 Guidelines says that "the term edition may be used for a particular state of a machine-readable text at which substantive changes are made and fixed. The words revision and update, by contrast, are used for minor changes to a file which do not amount to a new edition. No simple rule can specify how ‘substantive’ changes have to be before they are regarded as producing a new edition, rather than a simple update. The general principle proposed here is that the production of a new edition entails a significant change in the intellectual content of the file, rather than its encoding or appearance. " For 84000 texts, the element should include a version number or name and can include the date element.

According to the TEI P5 Guidelines, editionStmt (edition statement) is the second component of the fileDesc element and groups information relating to one edition of a text. It is an optional element, but recommended. It follows directly after the /titleStmt, and proceeds the publicationStmt. There are 5 potential child elements that it can contain, but for 84000 texts, the only child element is the edition tag, and that element contains in turn the date element, the grandchild of the editionStmt element.

remarks.p: 84000 uses this element to tag foreign words throughout documents with exception for the titles of texts, which should be tagged with the title element. All instances of the foreign element must contain the xml:lang with its value following the ISO 639-1 codes; however, for any language that is not usually written in a Roman script (i.e., Sanskrit, Tibetan, Chinese, Pali, etc...), if the language is written in a Romanized script then the first letter should be capitalized and "-Ltn" should be added to the value. For example Sanskrit "sa" becomes "Sa-Ltn", Tibetan "bo" becomes "Bo-Ltn", Chinese "zh" becomes "Zh-Ltn" and so forth. But use, the regular ISO 639-1 code if the native script is used (usually this should only be the case with Tibetan "bo" or Chinese "zh"). Most instances of the foreign element should include the type attribute detailed above, although there are a few exceptions when foreign text will not fall into the "term" or "quote" category and this attribute is not needed, for instance, the case of Tibetan Wylie transliteration given in parenthesis after the phonetic rendering of a Tibetan name. However, in general romanized foreign names should not be tagged with the foreign element. This tag should only be used for foreign text that are to be italicized according to 84000's style guidelines, as our parser will italicize all instances of foreign text in the web display. There is one exception to this, in that text in the Tibetan and Chinese script should be tagged with the foreign element, but will not be italicized in the parser.

remarks.p: In the glossary found in the back material of each 84000 text, the gloss element wraps each glossary term with its variations in Tibetan and Sanskrit along with a definition. The gloss element is requires the xml:id attribute, and the type attribute declaring whether it is a "term", "person", "place", or "text". The first term element (which has no attributes and presents the English translation of the term) will create a link to the glossary in the reading room for each instance of that term as it appears as a string in the text. However, in some cases it may be inappropriate to link certain strings of text that match this term and so optionally the mode attribute may be added with the values of "marked" or "match". A gloss element with the mode "match" will match with all instances of that string in the text unless they are marked with <term rend="ignore">. A term in the glossary with the mode "marked" will only link to terms with the term element. of the term, that are marked also by term tags the type attribute with the value of "alternate".

There also may be occasions were the translator has used alternate translations for the same term, or different variations for the spelling of a string that correspond to the same glossary entry. In this case an additional term element should be added with the value "translationAlternative". This will cause the parser to link these alternate string instances of the text in 84000's reading room.

item.p: I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery when lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and then the city of the pretas.

1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama and describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and praises him.
II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell.
1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells, visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This very sūtra sounds in their realm.

item.p: i. When the JAA states that “non-arising” and “non-cessation” are epithets of the Tathāgata, it shows that the Buddha is unproduced.
ii. The nine examples explain what it means for the Tathāgata to be non-arising and non-cessation (given in the Ratna­gotra­vibhāga as the reason for his being unproduced).
iii. The explanations of all that has been pacified show that, since all his elaborations and concepts have been pacified, the Tathāgata is effortless with respect to his own activities.

iv. The next section shows that the Tathāgata realizes for himself the gates to the realization of the nature of all dharmas, and goes on to explain the sixteen features of the Tathāgata’s realization (this links to not arisen by understanding from others).
v. One sentence describes the Tathāgata’s great compassion, showing that he is endowed with unexcelled awareness and compassion.

exemplum.p: Here in this outline from Toh. 11 (See reading room display here). The label element and the <head type="list"> element are both used to great bold headers:

list.head: I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA
list.p: The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized. Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters, with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10.

item.label: Chapters 1 and 2
item.p: In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection of wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is the absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative experiences, all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional attributes manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including omniscience. along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of all things and the finality of existence, these are all attributes with respect to which a great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment. Bodhisattvas do perceive such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative level; in an ultimate sense they consider them to be illusory, in the manner of a dream and so forth.

item.label: Chapter 3
item.p: Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are considered as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or suffering, with self or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or signless, having or lacking aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void, afflicted or purified, arising or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as entities or non-entities. Deluded minds would view these phenomena and attributes as absolutely existent whereas bodhisattvas should train so as to understand that they are all non-apprehensible—mere designations and conceptualizations.

remarks.p: In general list elements may be used to demarcate a formal list anywhere in the text. As a standard, lists are used in the "notes" section to list the source material abbreviations key and used in the "glossary" section to list individual glossary entries. Additionally, lists may be used to create outlines or formal lists within the text. Each list must contain items, which contain the individual items on a list. When creating an outline or formal list within the text, the type="section" or type="bullet" must be used. In the web display, type="section" will render items with some vertical spacing between each item, type="bullet" will not have vertical spacing, but will be indented. Multiple list elements in combination with these types to format an outline. For example see this outline in Toh. 116 and the XML markup in the example below. For further details on creating outlines see Appendix B Topics .

A list may contain a <head type="list"> element to create a bold heading at the beginning before the first item in the list. Within each item, a label element can be used to the same effect. See in the XML example below from Toh. 11

Note that lists along with their items can be generated from the template .docx passed through our XSLT script. In MS Word, lists are auto-generated either by clicking the list icons on the menu bar or by entering a "1" or "*" and on a new line and hitting the space key. These lists will be rendered by the XSLT script with nested list and item tags. It can render multi-leveled lists or outlines, however they need to be auto-generated list in MS Word for them to pass through the script; you can determine that they are auto-generated when in MS Word the cursor will skip over the bullet point or numbered prefix of the list when passed across with the arrow keys. The first level list will be tagged type="bullet" by default, but second level lists and beyond will need the type attribute to be entered manually.

remarks.p: In the texts, we use the milestone tag to develop as artificial demarcations of the text that will eventually allow people to refer to parts of a text in a somewhat standardized manner. Because there are no consistent natural break points in the original Tibetan texts, the 84000 team decided to use milestone tags. They represent small amounts of texts that are in someway semantically cohesive. They are not tied to a specific text length, but they are not more than a few paragraphs. See the instructions for entering milestones into the text in the Appendix .

Manually Changing the Milestone Numbers: Note that the milestone numbers displayed in the text are automatically generated, so the first section/chapter will display: 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, etc. However, the number after the period can be modified with the @n attribute, and the initial section number may be modified in the div with a @prefix attribute. note.p: Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for cataloging the Toh 1001 version of this text within vol. 101 or 102 of the Degé Kangyur. See Toh 1001, note 6, for details.

This text, Toh 1001, and all those contained in this same volume (gzungs, waM), are listed as being located in volume 101 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located in volume 102. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ’dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantra­ṭīkā (dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chags (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.

q.p: “Blessed One, there is an extensive collection of discourses on the Dharma that bears the name Lalitavistara (The Play in Full). This teaching illuminates the basic virtues of the bodhisattvas, showing how the Bodhisattva descended from the sublime palace in the Heaven of Joy, intentionally entered the womb, and sojourned in the womb. It shows the power of the place where he was born to a noble family, and how he surpassed others through all the superior special qualities that he demonstrated through his actions as a youth. It shows his many unique qualities, such as his skills in arts, crafts, writing, arithmetic, calculations, astrology, fencing, archery, feats of physical strength, and wrestling, demonstrating his superiority to all others in these areas. It shows how he enjoyed his retinue of consorts and the pleasures of his kingdom.

“This teaching proclaims how he attained the result brought about by the concordant cause of all the bodhisattva activities, showing how he manifested as a bodhisattva and destroyed the legions of Māra. It explains the ten powers, the fourfold fearlessness, and the other innumerable qualities of a thus-gone one, and presents the infinite teachings taught by the thus-gone ones of times past.”

remarks.p: If it has the value "hidden" it will not be displayed in the reading room. This is useful if these references are unnecessary and would be excessive for the typical reader, but should be embedded in the text for the purposes of research. For example, some of the folio refs for the Sanskrit in Toh. 11 are hidden in this way, but there is a note about their availability in the text's introduction. See the example below.

The value "pending" is only used for references to be linked to other 84000 texts that are not yet published. The URL to the page of the unpublished texts should still be applied to the @target attribute of the ref, e.g., target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh9999.html" But the link will not become active until the @rend="pending" is removed. This @target needs to be added so that the ref will be flagged at the time the unpublished text is published. Furthermore, if the reference points to a particular page in the unpublished text, e.g., a folio number, this should be added as an inst attribute so that the appropriate milestone can be located and added to the URL at the time the text is published. See example below.

The value "blank" is used if the corresponding folio in the eKangyur is blank. This should not be linked in the Reading Room view, and a note should be added to the grayed out reference, e.g., "This folio of the Degé Kangyur is blank." See for example Toh 287.

remarks.p: This attribute is needed for Kangyur (or Tengyur) folio references that do not refer to the default--for the Kangyur this is the eKangyur (UT4CZ5369). All Kangyur folio references should have a cRef ("canonical reference") attribute. In the reading room, refs will by default link to the eKangyur, so the work attribute is needed or else the parser will erroneously link to that folio in the eKangyur according to the cRef. When the work attribute is present, the parser will create a link to that work or leave the reference unlinked if the alternate work in not in the database.

remarks.p: When a link is made to an unpublished 84000 text using @rend="pending", if that reference points to a specific folio reference then that should be indicated in the inst attribute with the value of the folio number, e.g., inst="F.100.a". When the target text is published, this specific milestone needs to be manually located by the markup editor, and the inst attribute may then be removed. Note that any brief statement of additional instructions for finding the appropriate milestone can be added to the value, for example, inst="F.100.a-speech by so and so...". If there is no specific page number, but the reference just links to the front page of the text, then do not use the inst attribute.

Bampo references should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "bampo" and follow the format "B[bampo number]", for example:

remarks.p: Tables contains an optional heading and a series of rows. Generally the style of the table will be generated automatically by the parser and the width of each column and row will be determined by the longest string of text in that column or row; however if the default table is rendered ineloquently in the HTML, as an option the rend attribute may be used to define the width of the first column: @rend="firstcol-30pc" will set the width of the first column to 30% of the width of the full table, "firstcol-40pc" and "firstcol-50pc" will set it to 40% and 50% respectively. This was used, for example, in the appendix of Toh 307 to display the tables there with a consistent column width in relation to each other.

Currently no type is being used, but this may be added to the schema and documentation when it becomes necessary. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent cells are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a row contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child cells will be considered to be "label"s as well.

Note, when marking up tables the markup editor should check that the table renders properly in the reading room's web display. In addition, the table needs to be checked in the ebook display as well. This can be done by adding the code: ?viewmode=epub to the very end of the url address on the utilities page. In truth, the tables are not compatible with the ebook format, so the parser will instead display them as a bulleted list. The information in this list should be presented in a complete and eloquently readable way, otherwise the parser should be updated.
For further details on tables see Appendix B Topics: .

remarks.p: The following description from the University of Michigan is available as part of a PDF at http://www.lib.umich.edu/files/departments/dpp/20101113_06.pdf "The TEI header (teiHeader) is the ‘virtual title page’ of a TEI document. It contains meta data (information about the TEI document). teiHeader is the first, mandatory child element of the root TEI element; therefore, it appears at the top (‘at the head’) of every TEI document. The header meta data provides: 1. bibliographic record of the electronic text as well as the source from which the electronic text is derived 2. documentation of the encoding and editorial principles used in tagging the electronic text 3. terms for indexing, searching, and retrieval 4. a record of changes made to the electronic document. The header contains many specialised elements not found anywhere in the ‘body’ of a TEI document (that is, everything after the close of teiHeader). These elements allow for highly structured descriptions of the document. Many parts of the header allow free-form prose descriptions as an alternative to the highly structured descriptions. Few header elements are required, so a header can be quite minimal."

exemplum.p: Primarily the term element is used to list glossary terms in the back matter of a text. For each individual gloss element, which constitutes a single glossary entry, a list of several term elements are used (see the example below). The first term element, which should have no attritutes, shows the English translation of the term or the string used in for that term as it is found in the text. This first term element indicates to the parser which word or string of text to link to the glossary entry, and it will create a link for every instance of that term that is found in the text. The next term elements that follow within the gloss list the Wylie, Tibetan, and Sanskrit for that term, all indicated by the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate value. After that a definition is given in its own term element with the type="definition" attribute. Finally, if there are any alternate translations used for the term within the text that should be linked to this gloss, they are listed last each marked by type="translationAlternative". These instances of alternative strings of text will also be linked to the glossary entry wherever they are found in the text. All of this can be seen in the first example below. For further notes about the glossary see Appendix: .

exemplum.p: The term element may also be used in the text itself to alter the way a string of text is to be linked to the glossary. For example, a string of text can bypass being linked if it is placed within a term rend="ignore" as like the following example. Alternatively, if the parent gloss element for an entry is given the attribute mode="marked" then it will only link to instances in the text that are contained within a term element. If there are three or more glossary entries of the same string, then these may be more precisely distinguished within the body of text by adding a @ref attribute pointing to the specific glossary entry to which they refer (In this situations the gloss entry should be mode="marked"). For more details on how the glossary functions on the web page see Appendix: .

Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, appropriate another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it appropriate different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?”

remarks.p: Appears once in the teiHeader. It should contain the nine title variations for each text. This should include four "mainTitle"s and four "longTitle"s (for Wylie, Tibetan, English, and Sanskrit); and one "otherTitle" (for Chinese). If any of these nine default titles are not present, they should contain an empty element as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. It may contain additional title(s) from other sources, but these should be marked as type="otherTitle". Following the titles, there needs to be author elements given for each person or group involved in the translation of the text (these authors are the translators of the English, not the original translators of the Tibetan who will be listed later on in the sourceDesc). After the authors, any editors, consultants, or sponsors may be listed in that order. For these latter three, DO NOT leave empty elements as placeholders if they are not present.

attDef.desc: Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text. It is also applicable to trailers which replace the p element.
Identify in which text this element is to be displayed if there are more than one.

valItem.desc: Part of an output template, this will remain invisible until rend="default-text" is removed.

egXML.trailer: This concludes the first chapter, the introduction to the tantra, in the glorious Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa tantra called “The Sole Hero.”

exemplum.p: Like the p element, the trailer may contain notes or refs, as like the following example.

egXML.trailer: Conclusion of the third chapter, “Praise of the Buddha’s Qualities.” According to the commentary, the title of this chapter is “Mindfulness of the Buddha’s Qualities.”

p.tei:ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)

remarks.p: The trailer should be used for the last sentence of a chapter or text that declares it is the end of that chapter or text. This doesn't include colophons. This element functions like the paragraph, p, element and may require a milestone preceding it, and the tid attribute. In the final web display the trailer will be italicized. All of the trailers will be separated by a space and italicized in their entirety by the parser, so any titles that appear in the trailer should be giving curled quotations marks to indicate that it is a title.

elementSpec.desc: Used in the location to define the volume(s) in which the text is located.

remarks.p: Identifies the volume of the text. This element is key for determining the alignment of the folio references linked to the eKangyur.

div.head: Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors
div.p: Following below are complete step-by-step guidelines for marking up 84000 TEI. To reference how the markup stage is integrated with the entire 84000 workflow, here is link to the Editorial and Publications Workflow document.

div.head: Check the MS Word Document from Project Management
div.p: According to our current workflow, when a text is passed to markup it should be already uploaded to project management. First click on the "Search" tab and locate the file using the Toh number. Once you have found the text click on "edit headers", from there you can expand the "submissions" section (The TEI will be generated from this same screen as well, see below). From here you may click on the document and download it in order to check the document from MS Word. The copyeditors will have entered most of the proper style tags for foreign terms, verses, some of the mantra markup, and so forth. However, when you begin a text it is important to double check the work and make sure the text has been entered properly into the template. Also, sometimes you may be asked to apply the style tags into the template yourself, so as you continue to edit TEI markup, you should occasionally read the instructions in the copy editor's template and try to become familiar with them (The latest version of the copy editor's template may be downloaded here). A lot of the tags are set up to be tagged with character and paragraph styles from the template and automatically converted by a script into to correct markup. However, the copy editors may occasionally make some mistakes, and being familiar with the template will help you correct them and inform the copy editors of any issues. Remember, sections can always be corrected from the template, passed through the script again, and pasted into the final TEI so keep the original word document open for reference while you work.
When checking the document please follow check that the following is applied in the DOCX:

list.item: In general you can corraborate with the instructions written in the template.

Check that the text has tagged the appropriate sections using the "Heading 1, 2, 3, etc" headings. The "Heading 1 and 2" styles should be embedded in the template, but the copy editor will add more headings as is needed. All of these headings will trigger the script to generate section divisions in the TEI. MS Word has heading styles up to "Heading 9". In the rare case that more are needed, hard tags will be used e.g. "<level 10 header>", which will need to be applied manually from Oxygen. If the editors have removed one of the default headings by accident it may cause a section to be missing in the converted TEI. One way to check is to look in under the view tab in MS word and check the box that says "Navigation Pane". This should show you an outline of the text from a side window, which should follow a layout according to the heading styles. "The Introduction" and "The Translation" should either be filled with subsections or just one default subsection that says "Main Section".
All the italics have been applied with the various character styles, "foreign-", "title-", etc. (don't worry though, if you miss some, those italics will be given a <fix> tag by the script).

Because the markup for mantras has become a bit complicated, we have provided the copy editors an "Option Two" for applying style tags to all the mantras. This instruction was given in case differentiating the different "mantra" styles becomes too distracting from the actual copy editing work. Under "Option Two," the copy editor will tag all of the mantra italics with the character style "Mantra-Other" and you will need to distinguish and apply the appropriate markup to the mantras. You can do this either now, while you are checking the template, or you can pass the template through the script as it is and all the mantras will be tagged <mantra type="input type" xml:lang="input language"> and you can mark them up in the XML. However, I recommend doing this from the template as it will be faster. You can quickly find all the "Mantra-Other" tags by doing an "advanced find and replace" and click on the Format --> "Style" in the search dialog box. Leave the search bar empty and you can quickly go through all the "Mantra-Other" styles in the entire template and apply the correct style from the style pane. See instructions for the mantra markup in the template II. MANTRAS, pp 3–5, or see the full documentation for the mantra markup here in Appendix B Topics .

All the verses have the "verse" paragraph style applied, and they are formatted correctly with line breaks between lines and paragraph breaks between stanzas (change the display settings to show paragraph marks and line breaks so you can see more clearly whether they are formatted correctly).

In some cases the copy editors may have left comments for the markup editors with the MS Word comments feature. The script will convert these into note elements that will have the "place" attribute with the value of "comment_from_copyeditor_to_markup_editor." I have intentionally set this up to be highlighted by the schema as an error, so that the copy editors may highlight any unusual formatting or other issues that need to be addressed by the markup editors. You may leave these in and address them as you work on the XML or alternatively keep a backup of the .docx and reference the comments from there. If you don't want to see them in the XML, make a backup of the .docx and select "Delete All Comments in the Document" from the review pane in Word before sending the document through the conversion script.

div.p: If the document looks good, you can go ahead and run the script, otherwise make corrections and upload the document again. If so, please use the exact same file name but add "-v2" or "-v3"... etc. for any subsequent versions for example: "T747-bhutadamara-for-markup-apr-16-2020-v2". Upload it to project management with the /Submissions.
Don't worry, you can always go back and do this again later on if you notice some problem in the DOCX.

div.head: Transform the New DOCX To TEI-XML

head.hi: Running the Document through the Conversion Script:

list.item: Again using the "/Submissions" tab in Project Management, click on the document you wish to run through the script, and in the next panel, there will be a checklist on the right side of the screen. Check the "generate TEI" box, and then click save. The app will perform the conversion and the output .xml file can be found in the 84000 Collaboration/apps/84000-import-data folder. There will be a unique folder created with the name of the texts xml:id number. Note that you can convert the glossary through this submissions form as well (although this should be done later after checking the document, see Appendix: .

Occasionally the app may be down or the project management page may give you a permissions error. If it says that permission is denied you should email the lead technician who handles the server's permissions (Dominic). Alternatively, it is also possible to convert the word .docx created in the template through the oXgarage website or it's mirror site. Convert the file to a "TEI P5 XML Document" and run our own .xslt script on the document. The .xslt script is in apps/84000-import-data/xsl. (Instructions for running an .xslt script can be found in the Appendix: )

head.hi: Checking the XML Conversion before You Begin Editing:

list.item: This should create a file that is closer to what we want. However, the script is definitely not perfect, and many sections will need some reworking.

If the "verse" styles were applied appropriately in the template, then the script should put them correctly into lg and l elements. It should also preserve and convert any italic markup within the verses. The script is able to do both because in MS Word the "verse" is a paragraph style and all the italic markups are character styles. However, for the script to work properly the individual lines of verse need to be separated by line breaks, and the stanzas themselves need to be separated by paragraph breaks. There are instructions for how to do this in the template, but this process can be a bit finicky, so you should double check some of the verses to make sure the conversion has worked properly. Refer to the section on the lg element to see how verses need to be formatted.

Another note about the script to keep in mind is that the script is designed to automatically create divisions with div elements in the markup whenever the copy editors use the "heading 1," "heading 2," etc. styles in the template (up to "heading 9"). This will create the proper levels of divs. Any tenth level divs or further should be placed into tags by the copy editor and you will need to create the divs manually when you edit the XML. Occasionally, the copy editor will put a heading into the "heading 1" or "heading 2" style but they will mistakenly leave the paragraph break at the end of the heading's text in the "normal" style. The script generates the div elements according to these paragraph breaks, so in this case, it will not create the proper division. Usually it is easy enough to correct these in either the template .docx or in the .xml, but in some cases it may save you some time if you can identify and fix them before the conversion. For example, this happened in the bibliography of a text, and because the bibliography entries were nested with one div instead of two, the script rendered them into p elements instead of bibl elements as is required.

The script has a section for making appendices, which should appear in the back after the bibliography. However, since not all the texts have appendices, and since appendices could appear in many different forms such as lists, outlines, Sanskrit sources, etc., the script only converts these into the minimal default paragraphs or verses. You may need to reformat the markup in the section extensively or paste it in from the word file and mark it up from there. If there are more appendices in the future, or a particularly large appendix that needs to be extensively edited, we will develop the script to convert the appendices in a more detailed way.

If there is some unusual formatting or other issue that is preventing the script from converting the text properly, one strategy for isolating the problem is to divide the text into three pieces (front material, body, and back material), convert each section one be one, and then paste them into the final .xml. In this case do the conversion through oxGarage (Instructions for this are found in the Appendix: ).

div.head: Merging the Converted XML into the Placeholder File

head.hi: Merge the Converted XML into the Placeholder File:

list.item: When you have finished converting the document into an TEI-XML file, it is time to transfer it into the translations folder. There should already be a placeholder file for each of the Kangyur and Tengyur texts. Go to 84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > tei > translations, and you will see the "kangyur" and "tengyur" folders. Each of these folders in turn contain a "placeholders" folder and a "translations" folder. Find the placeholder file right click and select "cut" then move it into the sibling "translations" folder by right and select "paste" (don't use "copy" and "paste" as this will reset the files permissions).

Now please change the file name to reflect what has been given as an English title by the translator. The previous title was translated before the project, so we want the filename to be consistent with what the translator has given. ***Important: please don't use any apostrophes or diacritics in the filename and remove any that happen to be there, as these will create problems for the server.

You can then begin pasting the text from the XML you just converted into the placeholder text. The placeholder files usually just contain the teiHeader, however, most of this is important information and should not be overwritten. The converted XML will have directions in the form of comments, which will tell you specifically what elements within the teiHeader need to be added to the placeholder, and which to be left as is. In general, try to preserve all pertinent information from both sources, and if there is any data that seems to be contradictory, comment out the additional data and make a note of this in your final list of notes and issues.

The placeholder's titleStmt will require some extra attention; this contains the original collection of titles given to texts when the 84000 project first begin. However, when translations for these texts are made there will likely be many changes that need to be applied to the various titles. There may be additional alternative titles discovered through the translator's research, but there may be some alternative titles found in the placeholder file that the translator did not notice. So when merging the titleStmt in the converted XML with the placehoder please use the following protocol:
Update any English title to the one used by the translator found in the converted XML.
Preserve any alternative titles found in either the converted XML or the placeholder file. Alternative titles should be labeled type="otherTitle"
Make sure that the Sanskrit and Tibetan short titles, i.e., "otherTitles", are consistent with the English title in terms of the prensense of the final "འི་མདོ།" or"-sūtra". These should be removed if the word "Sūtra" isn't also found in the corresponding short English title. This presence or absence of "Sūtra" is not significant enough to warrant adding an additional "alternativeTitle"
Sanskrit Titles should have the first letter capitalized.
There should be a minimum of nine titles: 4 Main Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), 4 Long Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), and 1 Chinese. Any additional variant titles (whether coming from the converted file or already present in the placeholder) should be added after this as type="otherTitle". The actual order of the titles doesn't matter because the parser will display them in the same order no matter what order the XML is in, but if one or more of the nine default titles are not present, leave an empty element there as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. Here is an example of the nine titles from Toh 65: The Prophecy for Bhadra the Illusionist Bhadra­māyākāravyākaraṇa སྒྱུ་མ་མཁན་བཟང་པོ་ལུང་བསྟན་པ། sgyu ma mkhan bzang po lung bstan pa The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Prophecy for Bhadra the Illusionist” Ārya­bhadramāyākāra­vyākaraṇa­nāma­mahāyāna­sūtra འཕགས་པ་སྒྱུ་མ་མཁན་བཟང་པོ་ལུང་བསྟན་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ། ’phags pa sgyu ma mkhan bzang po lung bstan pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo 《幻師仁賢授記經》(大正藏:《大寶積經授幻師跋陀羅記會第二十一》
(See how this is displayed in the Reading Room)
Any straight single quote marks found in the Wylie should be changed to right curling ones. Note that all the Wylie in the placeholder titles will need to be changed because they have been left as straight quote marks in order to make them compatible with research databases like BDRC when the translator is in the research phase for that text. However, in our publications we only use curled ones.
The Tibetan Unicode titles "bo" should end with a shad ། but the Wylie titles "Bo-Ltn" should NOT end with a shad or backslash.
After the titles, the main translator or translator group will be listed in an <author role="translatorMain">. All the translations published before 2024 have a description here of the main translator group along with the phrase "translated by... under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha." However, from 2024 forward, we are no longer stating the translation group on the cover page and instead their names are given in the acknowledgments. (These older publications will also be revised eventually) However the <author role="translatorMain"> should still be listed here as an empty tag, which will contain the id of the main translation group, followed by any <author>, <consultant>, or <editor> tags listing the various contributors (all of these can also be edited from Project Management). Here is an example of the contributor list from Toh 65:
Celso Wilkinson Laura Goetz Lopon Damchoe Wangmo William Giddings L.S. Summer Celso Wilkinson Nathaniel Rich George FitzHerbert Dawn Collins Rory Lindsay Martina Cotter
You can reference title statement found in the TEI of Toh 65 if you need a template to work from.
Also check the original word document for additional titles as the conversion script is quite rigid, and some of them might disappear if they were not entered properly.

Occasionally, there will be a Chinese summary in the placeholder file, this should be merged into the TEI by placing the Chinese summary in its own div immediately after the English summary, for example:
Summary
On Gayāśīrṣa Hill, Buddha Śākyamuni is visited by a great gathering of bodhisattvas... [English Summary Here]
《寶雲經》是最早被翻譯成藏文的佛典之一... [Chinese Summary Here]
The Chinese will not be displayed in the English web display, but will appear in the Chinese catalog.

Note if Chinese characters are found in the sponsorship statement in the Acknowledgements: Sponsors are asked for what statement they would like give in the publication. Occasionally, these may be given in Chinese characters without translation or transliteration. For example here in Toh 543. So if you see this in the acknowledgements it is perfectly acceptable if that is what the sponsors request. Although, if you see it like this do make a note in the Reading Room Worksheet to confirm their choice in the final proofing stage.

Following the titleStmt, there are other sections in the teiHeader that need to be merged with those found in the placeholder file. There are specific instructions for merging each section of the teiHeader that will be provided as comments in the TEI file that was converted by the script. Please read through and follow these comments, which will tell you how to merge each section.
Since the merge process is a bit complicated, you may want to refer to the teiHeader in Toh 83 for reference. All the headers should follow the same format that has been used in Toh 83.
After the teiHeader is merged, the remaining text can be directly pasted into the placeholder file and the rest of the markup of can be completed here.

head.hi: A Note about Text Status and Project Management:

list.item: Note that the teiHeader can also be edited from the project management page. The forms found on the project management page can edit the elements in the TEI; this way editors and administration can edit these fields without access to Oxygen.

The text "status" can be changed from project management, but it can also be edited directly in the TEI as an attribute in the availability. Through the whole markup phase the text status should be "2.a" indicating that markup is in process. It should already be at that stage when arriving in markup. Note that it needs to be at stage "2.a" or later for the text to be displayed from the Utilities page. When you are completed with all the markup, it will be reviewed one more time by the lead markup editor and then they will update the status to "2", ("Markup Completed, and awaiting final proofing before release").

The schema should already be applied to the placeholder file, but if you need to apply the schema directly it is located in “84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > schema > current > translation.rng.” You will see any schema errors as red bars on the right column in the oXygen window. Checking the schema is the best way to see if the XML is going to work correctly in the parser. If later on you have trouble saving to the database, or if you can save to the database but the web page does not display the text, then start by checking for schema errors in oXygen. If it says that there is an error where you don’t think there is really an error, but you need to check the XML on the web display, you can comment-out that section with comment tags:
<!-- --> (or highlight and press Ctrl-Shift “,” on PC or Command-Shift "m" on mac). Then you will be able to temporarily block all the seeming schema errors to help identify the problem.

You will initially see many schema errors for some missing attributes such as "xml:id"s and "tid"s. Note that all "xml:id" attributes, "tid" attributes in the p elements, and "index" attributes in the note elements will be added automatically when you save and reload the XML, so you don't need to worry about adding these. However, in the teiHeader within the publicationStmt there is an element for the id number for the text, idno. This should have been already present in the placeholder folder, however if it is missing retrieve it from your manager and enter it in manually as this is needed to generate all the xml:id attributes in the text.

In case there is an error in any of the "xml:id" or "tid" attributes due to duplicates, then you can regenerate them by deleting any problematic ones, saving the file, and then re-opening. The "xml:id" and "tid" will be generated wherever they are missing. If not, email the lead technician and they will make sure they are regenerated. It is fine if the "xml:id" attributes are not in order as long as they each have a unique value.

head.hi: Some General Guidelines for Editing the XML:

list.item:
While editing the XML, I usually use a previously edited and published TEI document as a model to make sure everything is formatted in the same way. This can be helpful, especially if this is your first time marking up a text or if you haven't done the markup for some time. Toh 83 is our go to as the standard for markup. This is a simple text, one of our earliest publications, and the first place we look when assuring that our markup is consistent. Toh 83 is a good standard, although because it is a simple text it may not have references for how to deal with the markup used in special cases. Here are some other texts with published TEI, which you may refer to for specific markup situations:
For a text containing a lot of mantras: see Toh 431
For a text with a complex outline (containing 6+ levels of divs): see Toh 1-1
For a text with extensive Chinese quotations in the notes: see Toh 61 Also, if you are looking for a specific element try right clicking on the published "translations" folder and searching for a specific example to reference, e.g., "<table" to find a reference of the table element.

In general, while going through the text, it is important to periodically refer back to the .docx you received from the copy editor. If the document has an unusually formatted outline, some portions of text may be lost in the XSLT conversion. A good way to check this is to open the original .docx and look at the outline of the text (on PC go to “View” and check the box that says “Show Navigation Pane”; on Mac go to “View” > “Sidebar” > “Document Map Pane”; this might be different for other versions of Word). For example, if there are any fourth-level headers or extra divisions in the summary or acknowledgements, these sections may disappear. It is particularly good to check the front material and the bibliography for anything unusual.

The template should generate a placeholder for sponsorship in the Acknowledgements section (e.g. "[Sponsored by XXXXX.]"), this is just a placeholder for the sponsor so the editors and Line remember to check the sponsorship with Jing Rui before publication. Please leave it as is unless instructions from management say otherwise.

The acknowledgements section should be formatted in the following manner:
Main/external translator acknowledgements
Supervision of 84000 acknowledgement
<break> (convert this to an lb element)
Sponsorship acknowledgement for example:
Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the supervision of Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche. The translation was produced by Thomas Doctor with help from Benjamin Collet-Cassart and Timothy Hinkle. Thomas also wrote the introduction. Andreas Doctor checked the translation against the Tibetan and edited the text. David Higgins subsequently reviewed the translation and made further edits. Wiesiek Mical assisted by reviewing numerous passages against the available Sanskrit sources. Robert Kritzer generously shared several unpublished articles on the text with us and Vesna Wallace and Mitsuyo Demoto kindly gave us access to drafts of their critical Sanskrit editions of chapters 1 and 3, respectively.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha. John Canti and Andreas Doctor edited the translation and the introduction, and Ven. Konchog Norbu copyedited the text. TECHNICAL EDITOR was in charge of the digital publication process.
[Sponsored by XXXXX.]
You should then replace "TECHNICAL EDITOR" with your name if it hasn't been added already. (Note, the second paragraph in the sample above with 84000 acknowledgement follows one of the variant formats given in the copy editor's template. If you need to reference those formats, see the acknowledgements section in the copy editor's template.
Also, if you happen to notice, please check that "Ven." is added in front for any monastic members the translation team.

When you first get to the body of the text, you may notice that the title has been repeated with two lines containing separate p and milestone tags. For example:
The Translation
The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra
Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality
The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra
Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality
The reason for this, is the script has a safeguard to display any text within the first main div but not included in the first second level div. A not ideal consequence of this safeguard results in this repetition of the first two lines, which simply needed to be deleted manually. So the above example should be edited to look as follows:
The Translation
The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra
Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality

If either one of the introduction, main translation, and/or bibliography have only one section you will probably see this heading at the beginning of their second level div element:
Main Section This is actually a placeholder from the template and should be removed, as the heading from the previous div element will provide the heading "Introduction" or "The Translation."

Most Kangyur texts begin with a short homage, typically this should be followed by a line break lb between the homage and the beginning of the text, which needs to be added manually:
Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas!
Thus have I heard at one time.
(Click here to see in Reading Room display) Occasionally there may be a long homage that necessitates its own section. In this case it may be appropriate to create a div for the homage itself. The div and its accompanying head should both be type="homage". See for example in Toh 138:
Homage
Homage to the thus-gone Splendorous with the Gentle Glow of Light and Fragrance!
Homage to the one with the melodious voice of Mahābrahmā!
Having paid homage to him,
(Click here to see in Reading Room display)

If there were any italics that were missed in the copy editing phase, they will appear with a schema error in an element called "fix." You will need to manually fix these and replace them with the appropriate element, whether it be foreign, title, distinct, mantra etc. Sometimes these may be just italicized punctuation that the copy editor or author made by mistake, in which case you can go ahead and remove these tags.

Any foreign or title tags that are not tagged as English, Sanskrit, or Tibetan language, will need to have their @xml:lang tag entered in manually. These will all be highlighted by a schema error for the value of @xml:lang="Input_Language". In each case please apply the appropriate language code (the list of language codes can be referenced in the documentation for the foreign element.

Check that all mantras have been properly tagged. Note, that any mantras that have fragments of them written in more than one languages--usually English with Sanskrit seed syllables but this may also include Sanskrit/Tibetan mixed mantras--will be marked as such in the template and be converted to <foreign type="Fragment-in-MixedMantra">. They will appear as errors in the schema which is a signal for you to wrap the complete mantra in a <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> element. Then the @type="Fragment-in-MixedMantra" can be removed with the refactoring tool once they are all wrapped. mantras need to be tagged in precise way, please see Appendix B Topics: for details on how to markup the mantras.

Double check that the tag <hi rend="small-caps"> is used for any small capital letters in the text. This includes any abbreviations for CE ("Common Era") or BCE ("Before Common Era") in dates. Note that the lowercase letter needs to be used for small-caps, for example: In the year 2000 bce Then the parser will render this as small capital "BCE".
(If for some reason you ever need to add diacritics to small-caps, see details about this in the documentation for the hi element).

Note that some of the Kangyur sigla in the abbreviations and notes use subscript letters. For Kangyur sigla we use the Vienna system, which you can check the spelling here. Most of the sigla use a Capital letter followed by a lowercase one, but the sigla from the Peking Group, Mongolian, and Nyingma Kangyurs use a capital letter followed by subscript letters, and these second letters should have the <hi rend="subscript"> tag. Here either the lowercase or uppercase letter should be used according to the definitive sigla, for example: Peking 1737 PK = KQ, rnying rgyud bris ma = Gbm. Do not use any unicode for the small caps or subscript such as "ʙᴄᴇ" or "ᵥ" as this won't display consistently in the reading room for all browsers. The script should convert all small-caps and subscript from the template with the proper tag, if "small-caps" and "subscript" were applied in the template using MS Words Font dialog (Format > Font), but these should be double checked in the XML.
Look for any weird tags that shouldn't be there like "type="endnote text"" or any other relics from the oxgarage/script conversion.
Look for any mistakes: typos, mislabeled tags, etc.

Note that ellipses were previously made with three periods and non-breaking spaces (U+00A0) before each of the periods. However, we have updated our standard to instead use a single Unicode ellipsis character: … There is occasionally some ambiguity as to whether punctuation coming before/after an ellipsis should have a space; documentation for how to determine the proper standard for such punctuation is found here.
As you do any major work on the text, it is a good idea to occasionally update the version number as a reference for file backups. For guidelines on how and when to do this, see Appendix: .

head.hi: Editing Folio, Bampo, and Other Page References in the XML:

list.item:
All the references such as [F.100.a], etc. need to be entered into ref elements with the "cRef" attribute, thus [F.100.a] should look like this:
Note that this is the standard we are using for all folio references: it should be an "F" followed by a period, a number, another period, and the letter "a" or "b." To put the bracketed folios into the ref element I usually use a search and replace with regular expressions. To do this open a find and replace box, check the "Regular Expressions" box and search for: \[(F\.\d+\.[ab])\] Replace with:
Or if they forgot to add the second period before that "a" or "b," like "[F.100a]", then search for: \[(F\.\d+)([ab])\] And replace with:
Another situation you might see is double folios for duplicate Toh versions such as, "[(Toh 674) F.212.a] [(Toh 849) F.58.a]". Since you need to copy over the Toh # as the key, you can do that with a regular expression like this, search: \[\(Toh (\d+)\) (F\.\d+\.[ab])\] And replace:
Regular expressions are very useful for such tasks, just be careful not to search and replace any text or markup you did not intend to. For example, the introduction of a text might quote a folio reference number in the same format in which it was applied in the body of the text, say "[F.100.a]". We definitely don't want this instance placed into a ref element, so be careful not to inadvertently replace it with a "replace all" command. If you aren't familiar with regular expressions this is a good reference website, and there are a lot of tutorials on youtube too.

Sometimes there are other reference numbers used within the texts such as bampo numbers or page numbers referencing another source. All of these should also be placed in ref elements using the following conventions:
Bampo references should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "bampo" and follow the format "B[bampo number]", for example:
References to a Sanskrit, Chinese, or other source should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "sanskrit", "chinese" etc. Typically curly brackets should be used to differentiate the Sanskrit or Chinese references from the Tibetan ones. Because the parser automatically generates square brackets around the cRef attribute, the inner node of the ref element should be used with typed curly brackets, for example: {S1}
Note that whatever is placed in the @cRef attribute, will appear in square brackets in the reading room. Occasionally the author or editors may wish to hide a certain of reference number if they are deemed to be unnecessary for the general readership. In this case they may be given the attribute @rend="hidden", which will hide the reference in the reading room while still being marked in the TEI. For example this is done with some Sanskrit refs in Toh 11:
Note, here it doesn't matter whether the cRef is used or the inner node is used since it will be rendered invisible in the Reading Room.

When a ref comes between two paragraphs, it is better to place it at the end of the preceding paragraph rather than the beginning of proceeding one, as this will be less distracting for the reader. The very first ref, however, must be placed at the beginning of the paragraph as there is no other choice.

When a large text spans multiple volumes a volume reference should be added at the beginning of the new volume just before the first folio reference of the new volume using the following format: <ref type="volume" cRef="V__">. For example in Toh 11, it spans to volume 32 at F.92.b:
See how this is displayed in Reading Room
* Usually the new volume will reset to F.1.b, but Toh 11 is a special case and continues with the numbering "F.92.b" on the first page of volume 32. The volumes for the text will be marked in the location/volume element(s) in the located in the sourceDesc.

There are some texts that are duplicated in multiple sections of the Kangyur. For example The Prophecy of Sri_Mahadevi is found twice in the Kangyur as Toh. 193 and 739. Theses are both word for word exactly the same, but the folio references are going to be different for each duplicate version of the text. So in this situation we just use one TEI file, "061-014_toh193,739" but the folio references are differentiated with the key attribute which will relate each individual ref to the corresponding key that is declared within that version's bibl element found in the TEI's initial sourceDesc. For example, in 061-014_toh193,739's sourceDesc:
Toh 193 Degé Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 246.a–250.b Unknown
Toh 739 Degé Kangyur, vol. 94 (rgyud ’bum, tsha), folios 230.a–234.b Unknown
Then if you look at each individual folio references they will be differentiated by the key like this: ...
Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. Now the parser will only display the appropriate folio references, e.g., when you click on Toh. 193 it will show the references for Toh. 193 but not those for 739 and vice-versa. Sometimes the page breaks between the folios will be in the same place in the eKangyur but often they are different so you may need to go in and find them all manually if they were not written in by the translator.

As a final note on the subject of folio references, on rare occasions there are blank folio pages in the Degé appearing in the middle of texts. These blank pages will be matched with blank pages in the eKangyur; however, the reader generates a segment of preceding and following text from the nearest folio pages and this may be confusing to the reader when the folio reference is clicked in the web display. Therefore it is preferable to add a @rend="blank" attribute to any blank folios, which will suppress the link, and then add a note simply explaining that the page is blank. For example here is such a case in Toh 287: What difference is there This folio of the Degé Kangyur is blank. ... See how this is displayed in the Reading Room.

head.hi: Editing Tags that were Entered from the Template with Angular Brackets < > :

list.item:
There are a few special tags that copy editors have been instructed to enter into the template using angular brackets < and >. These include:
1) Modular passages: <module starts> <module ends>
2) Level ten sections or above: <level 10 div> </level 11 div> <level 12 div> </level 13 div> etc...
3) Block quotes: <q> </q>
4) Links to other Kangyur/Tengyur texts: <Reference Toh 9999 F.999.a>
5) Double line breaks used to create a section break without a header <break>
In each of these cases, in order to avoid nesting errors the angular brackets will be transformed by the script into their escape codes < and > respectively. In the xml editor these will appear in dark yellow type and can be easily searched for. Each should be addressed as follows:
1) modular passages, for now should just be replaced with comments, although just the tags themselves not their content, e.g.: ＆lt;module starts＆gt;Knowing and seeing all,＆lt;module ends＆gt; should be changed to
Knowing and seeing all, Some day we will create markup for this but for now, they are noted in comments that can be searched later.
2) Level ten sections or higher need div elements created for them along with any accompanying headers, e.g.: ＆lt;level 10 div＆gt;Section 1.2.1: Vinaya Rules Concerning Pet Alligators＆lt;/level 10 div＆gt; should be changed to
Section 1.2.1: Vinaya Rules Concerning Pet Alligators
3) Block quotes need to be changed into q elements. Any p or lg elements should be placed inside any q elements, e.g: ＆lt;q＆gt;
“Space has no abode;
It is free from elaboration, and stainless.
Your mind is the same as space,
And you are free of any point of reference:
I bow to you!” ＆lt;/q＆gt; should be changed to
“Space has no abode;
It is free from elaboration, and stainless.
Your mind is the same as space,
And you are free of any point of reference:
I bow to you!”
Occasionally the copy editors might forget to put in tags for block quotes. Therefore, refer back to the original .docx if it seems like a section should be put into block quotes. Add a note to the final list of questions and issues if there is a section that was not set apart as a block quote that you believe should have.
4) Links to other Kangyur/Tengyur texts should be created with ref, or if those texts are not yet published they should be given ref tags with the @rend="pending" attribute applied, e.g.: See The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant＆lt;Reference Toh 0282＆gt;. See The Perfection of Wisdom in One Million Lines＆lt;Reference Toh 4570＆gt; (a forthcoming 84000 publication). should be changed to See The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant See The Perfection of Wisdom in One Million Lines (a forthcoming 84000 publication). Please add these ref links and coded comments if they have been missed by the translator or copy editor. Note, that internal links are not made with the ref element, but rather with the ptr element. The compiled guidelines regarding how to create links are in the topics sections, see Appendix B Topics: for more details.
5) Replace ＆lt;break＆gt; with a simple lb tag.

head.hi: Other Issues to Check For while Editing the XML:

list.item:
Within the notes section of the text the template and script will create an abbreviations section even if there isn't one. If there isn't any abbreviations section in the original docx. you can delete the abbreviations header but leave the section for notes. It should just look like this:
Notes
If the translator used Kangyur sigla in the notes but didn't create an abbreviations section, you may need to add one. See details for this in Appendix B Topics: .

Any formal lists or outlines within the text should be marked up with the list element, which must also have the type attribute with the value "section" or "bullet." "Section" should be used for longer items of text, and it will render them with some vertical spacing between each item. "Bullet" should be used for shorter items and will create some horizontal indentation (it isn't necessary for there to be actual "bullets" in the list, this is just what we have named it). These types can be used in any combination to create an outline. For further details on outlines and some examples see Appendix B Topics: .

There may be times when a stanza of verse was missed and not placed into "verse" tags when being copy edited in the MS Word template. If that is the case you will notice each line of verse appearing in p tags rather than l tags. It is good to refer back to the original Word doc if you are in doubt, from there it should be clear according to the line breaks whether or not a stanza of verse was intended or not.
Occasionally there may be tables in a document. For instructions on how to markup tables see Appendix B Topics: .

Check that all the div elements are marked up with the proper type attributes. See the documentation for the div element to see the list of acceptable values. Note that a "prologue" or "colophon" should be marked as such and not as a "section." Also, each div should be accompanied by a head that has its own matching type attribute; however, there is one exception to this, <div type="section"> may be left without a head if the author did not provide one, this will usually be the case in the Introduction, Main Translation, or Bibliography whenever there is just one section and by default it is placed into a second level <div type="section"> wrapped within a first level <div type="introduction"> or <div type="translation">. In this case the parser will read the heads from the main first level div and the second level <div type="section"> will not require an additional head.

The script doesn't distinguish between chapters and sections, so the type value for all the "chapters" needs to be applied manually. Also, "chapter"s should contain a head type="chapter" element with some kind of enumeration, i.e., "chapter one," "chapter two," etc. If there is a formal title it should be contained in a head type="chapterHead" element following the first head. For example:
Chapter 32
The Teaching on the Nature of All Phenomena

Some texts have trailers at the end of each chapter, for example in Toh. 11:
This completes the twenty-second chapter from the Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom in Ten Thousand Lines, entitled “Cultivation.” Be default the script will convert every paragraph into a p element, so these trailers should be manually applied if they appear at the end of each chapter. Please give each trailer its own milestone.

All of the trailers will be separated by a space and italicized in their entirety by the parser, so any titles that appear in the trailer should be giving curled quotations marks. You will probably need to add these as the italicization could likely have been unnoticed in the copy editing phase. e.g.: This concludes the first chapter, the introduction to the tantra, in the glorious Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa tantra called “The Sole Hero.”

Some texts contain appendices. These will be located in the back section of the text. Usually the markup can be applied in the same way as in the main section, however, for Sanskrit Appendices (those that contain a Sanskrit edition of the text)see Appendix B Topics: for some further notes about marking up these sections.

As you are working with the TEI texts, you may encounter various problems that require you to search for specific pieces of code or text within the markup. The XQuery/XPath Builder is a useful tool for searching for specific instances of text. See Appendix: , for further details on how to use the XQuery/XPath Builder.

div.head: Edit Milestones
div.p: Milestones should be generated automatically by the script before every p element and lg element; however, we don't use milestones as uniformly as this, and many of the milestones will need to be taken out (For instructions on how to do this see Appendix: ). It is important to do an actual visual check of the milestones as they appear in the web display. From the Reading Room, take the perspective of the reader; there should be enough milestones to map out the text, but they should not be distracting to the actual narrative of the text.

div.head: Check the Alignment for Folio References
Check Alignment
div.p: First, we need to check to make sure the Folio References displayed on the web page are in alignment with the eKangyur. This require some minimal knowledge of Tibetan, so please have another editor check this for you if you don't know how to read Tibetan.

When you check the web display, go to the main translation and click on a folio reference, e.g., "[F.100.a]." This should cause the eKangyur text to pop up. Make sure that the eKangyur page that pops up is the correct page that corresponds to the English translation. You don't need to go through every folio in the text, just check the first two folio refs and the very last one.

Most likely they will already be aligned from the original placeholder data and a correction will not be needed. However, due to a blank page or error in the eKangyur the alignment of the pages might be off by one or more pages. The alignment may be adjusted in the location/volume element found in the sourceDesc; here the start-page and end-page define the span of the folio alignment according to the pages numbers of the eKangyur.

For texts that span two or more volumes, this will be defined by multiple volume elements and you should individual check the first and last folio for each volume. Then a <ref type="volume" cRef="V_"/> element needs to be added just before the first folio reference of the new volume. For example, Toh 11 spans two volumes:
and it jumps to volume 32 at F.92.b which is marked up as follows in the TEI:
See how this is displayed in Reading Room
* Note, usually the new volume will reset to F.1.b, but Toh 11 is a special case and continues with the numbering "F.92.b" on the first page of volume 32.

Please also check the Folios Utility from the main Utilities page. The folio utility will show you all the folio references along with their matching correlation in the eKangyur and then flag any anomalies. The anomalies will usually include the following:
Occasionally there may be a missing folio reference. It could be that the translator missed it or due to some formatting error the references were commented out or removed.
A folio reference may have been entered incorrectly (e.g. missing a period between the number and letter, "2b").
Differences between the spanning pages stated in the header and that found in the eKangyur. Although they are intended to be identical, there may be pagination differences between the Dege print the eKangyur is based on, W4CZ5369, and the official Dege print we use and reference in our biblScope, W22084 (Although the eKangyur uses the volume order from W22084).
Occasionally there may be anomalies reproduced from the original printed Dege, and certain page numbers may have been skipped or duplicated for various reasons.
Occasionally there may be an error in the pagination found in the eKangyur. (These can be corrected in the source files. Ask Celso about this). Any missing or erroneous folio references should be corrected (these flags should be in red). However, some of the flags will just not that the page number is logically out of alignment with the digital page order; e.g. the message, "Logically F.XXX.a/b" appearing next to the reference. This isn't necessarily a problem (which is why these flags are in yellow); it indicates that there is an anomaly between the logical page index in the digital file and the referenced folio number (the latter of which should correspond to the one displayed on the physical scan of the Tibetan source); usually because a folio number was skipped or there was a blank page in the Degé folio. Often the anomaly will originate on an earlier text in the same volume. So if you see these yellow flags, it's not necessarily a problem, but you should check to see if it originates in your text, and if so, that folios are aligned and displayed correctly with regards to that anomaly. For example, all the texts in vol. 90 are logically off by 1 page because there is a skipped folio page number on the first Tibetan folio of Toh 558. If you need to refer to the original scans, use the scan checker or check on BDRC W22084.
Note, that if the text contains duplicate versions within the Kangyur (such as Toh. 212/520/980), the folio alignment will need to be checked for each version individually.

div.head: Special Cases for Volumes 81 and 83 (only the very last texts), 88, and 100–102
div.p: ***Special Case for Volumes 81, 83, and 88 of the Degé Kangyur/eKangyur*** There is a variation due to the addition of texts in the post par phud printings, which includes our eKangyur in volumes 81, 83 and 88, which are not in the par phud printing such as W22084. In volumes 81 and 83, this only concerns some texts added to the very end of the volume, but for volume 88 the Bodhimaṇḍasyālaṃkāralakṣadhāraṇī (byang chub snying po’i rgyan ’bum gyi gzungs) has the same Tibetan title as Toh 509, but a different Sanskrit title (Toh 509 is Bodhigarbhālaṃkāralakṣadhāraṇī). While this is confusing, it is also presumably the reason why the extra text was inserted at this point. If the orginal translator used a par phud printing this then off sets Volume 88 by 17 folios for all texts after Toh. 508. Some points to address that should be addressed:
(1) First be sure that both versions are stated in the biblscope. See this example from Toh 526 this is the style that should be used as a template:

egXML.biblScope: Degé Kangyur, vol. 88 (rgyud, na), folios 54.a–54.b (in par phud printings), 71.a–71.b (in later printings)

div.p: (2) In this situation, because the folio references will not match up with those in the eKangyur, our solution has been to use both folio references. The one that links to the eKanyur will be the default ref element and the ref that refers to the alternate printing (likely W22084) should have this stated by a work attribute within the ref element. See for example from toh. 520:
