Here in the web display both references will be visible but only the one without the "work" attribute will have a clickable link to the eKangyur.

Please add a note after the first folio instance that explains this issue to the reader. If the text includes duplicates at different Toh numbers, then the note will need alternate messages, which are applied by using the @key attribute in the p elements within the note. The template for the note is as follows:

note.p: Two sets of folio references have been included in this translation due to a discrepancy in volume 88 (rgyud ’bum, na) of the Degé Kangyur between the 1737 par phud printings and the late (post par phud) printings. In the latter case, an extra work, Bodhi­maṇḍasyālaṃkāra­lakṣa­dhāraṇī (Toh 508, byang chub snying po’i rgyan ’bum gyi gzungs), was added as the second text in the volume, thereby displacing the pagination of all the following texts in the same volume by 17 folios. Since the eKangyur follows the later printing, both references have been provided, with the highlighted one linking to the eKangyur viewer.

In the Toh ### version of the text there is a slight discrepancy in the folio numbering between the 1737 par phud printings and the late (post par phud) printings of the Degé Kangyur. Although the discrepancy is irrelevant here, further details concerning this may be found in note # of the Toh ### version of this text.

div.p: That way the alternate text will display a shorter note that simply references the longer one (For example, see how the note is displayed differently in Toh 212 and Toh 520).

To confirm that the W22084 folio is correct please use the Dege-scan checking script. Note, that BDRC, AIBS, and even the Vienna site are not reliable in terms of distinguishing the "par phud" vs "post par phud" pagination in Vol. 88.

***Special Case for Volume 100, 101, and 102 of the Degé Kangyur*** These volumes are all misplaced by one volume in the eKangyur, so "volume 100" will be "volume 101" in the eKangyur, etc. If this is indeed the case, the adjustment should be made in the location found in the sourceDesc, however the biblscope should not be changed but reflect the correct volume as the text appears in the BDRC. For example, here is the sourceDesc for Toh 846a:

Additionally, a note about this discrepancy should be placed somewhere in the introduction. As before, if the text includes duplicates at different Toh numbers, then the note will need to include alternate messages applied by using the @key attribute in the p elements within the note. The template for this note is as follows:

note.p: This text, Toh ###, and all those contained in this same volume ( XXXX, X ), are listed as being located in volume ### of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located in volume ###. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ’dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantra­ṭīkā (dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chags (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.
Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for cataloging the Toh ### version of this text within vol. ### or ### of the Degé Kangyur. See Toh ####, note # , for details.

div.p: See an example how the note is displayed Toh 729 and Toh 1001

Please place the note in the introduction wherever it makes sense, for instance when explaining where the text is found in the Kangyur, and so on. Adapt it to the volume number, e.g., "gzung ’dus e", or as appropriate if the text appears in two volumes. If needed you can see how it was adapted and placed in the following examples that have already been approved by the editors of the texts: Toh 846, 846a, 847 (145), 848 (522), 980 (212, 520).

div.head: Edit the Glossary
div.p: Typically the glossary should be included as a set of tables in the 84000 .docx template, and it will be converted into TEI through the main script. However, in case an .xlsx file was used for the glossary, see the instructions for transforming the glossary from a spreadsheet in the sub-appendix here.

Note that for the glossary to be converted properly the tables need to be labeled correctly and the columns of the glossary placed in the correct order; this should all be set up in the template, however, if you get weird results, double check that the tables were set up properly and make any corrections to the .docx as is needed:
There should be three or four tables with a 'Heading 1' style labeled: "Terms", "People", "Places", and on occasion there will be a fourth sheet that should be labeled "Texts". If the labels of the sheets aren't spelled exactly like this, then the script won't apply the correct type to the gloss elements.
Each sheet/table needs to have seven columns that are to be exactly arranged as follows: (A) Tibetan Wylie, (B) Sanskrit, (C) Skt Source, (D) Chinese (optional), (E) Translation, (F)Definition, and (G) Alternatives. (See also the template in the shared google drive). Outdated templates may only have five columns and so the missing ones can be filled by right clicking and inserting blank ones from MS Word.

div.head: General notes on Editing the Glossary:

list.item: Edit the glossary. Note that when you save the file to the database it will add the “xml:id” automatically so you don’t need to worry about adding these. You will probably need to remove several empty item elements that were converted from empty cells at the bottom of each sheet. Also remove entries that were converted from the spreadsheet's headings i.e., Tibetan, Sanskrit, Translation, Definition, etc.

If Chinese terms were in the fourth column of the table, those Chinese terms will be assumed to be Chinese characters and will be set to xml:lang="zh" by default. If they are actually romanized transliteration of Chinese then the xml:lang attribute should ="Zh-Ltn"

Note that the database will also automatically generate Tibetan script and add it as a <term xml:lang="bo"/> element based on the Wylie glossary entries. The code should look within the glossary for any <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"/> and create the matching "bo" term wherever there isn't one. So be sure to save the file, close it, reopen, and check that the Tibetan entries have been properly added.

Check for errors and make sure the tags are nested properly. Use a previously-edited 84000 TEI XML as a model. You might want to save it first so that it automatically adds all the attributes and so forth.

If you used the spreadsheet, then by default the script will place all italics found in the definitions column into <fix> tags, and you will need to go in and change these into the proper tags and add the proper type and xml:lang attributes as needed. For the template these tags should all be generated according to the styles used within the template (or it will tag them with <fix> if any italics were missed).

div.head: Check for Wylie Errors and Verify the Tibetan Spelling:

list.item: Often many spelling typos can slip through into the glossaries without even the editors being aware. The markup provides a final check to assure that spelling errors don't fall through and contaminate the cumulative glossary. You are in an apt position to do this because the script will generate Tibetan Unicode from the Wylie input and spelling errors are much easier to spot in the Tibetan script displayed from the reading room or glossary editing app. You can either check the entries Tibetan spelling now, or if you prefer do it when you look through the final web display (Step A.11), just please be sure to make a thorough check at some point in the markup process. There are two methods for checking the Tibetan spelling:

The Glossary App from Project Management is very helpful, and for shorter texts this is the easiest way to check that the terms are spelled correctly, by seeing their direct correspondence in the eKangyur. To open the Glossary App go to Project Management and select the "Edit Glossary" link next to the text.

Unfortunately the Glossary App currently has a lot of lag and will not be efficient for larger texts. For larger texts, I suggest downloading the eKangyur text and searching it with a fast text editor that displays Tibetan Unicode (Atom, Sublime Text, Notepad++). To obtain a digital eKangyur version of any text for searching in the text editor, go to Utilities and click on the version that says "...bo.txt" for example, "toh83-bo.txt". I prefer to search the files with a line break at each folio ref and simplify the confusing tags. To do this enable regex search-and-replace in your text editor and use the following regex:

item.p: SEARCH:
REPLACE:

list.item: Go through every glossary item, if anything looks like it could be misspelled, or if you are not certain about the spelling of that term, check it against the eKangyur.

Particles: Beware of misspelled particles; very often an incorrect case particle (དུ་ཏུ་སུ་-ར་ -- ཀྱི་གྱི་གི་-འི་), these are very easy for the editors to miss, and if they slip through they will create problems for the cumulative glossary, so if anything looks suspicious please double check it against the eKangyur.

Archaic Spelling Forms: Occasionally there are archaic spellings or alternate spelling preserved in the eKangyur, so if something looks misspelled, please confer first with the Kangyur, as it does contain many unusual spelling forms that I assume we want to preserve. If the translator entered a more standard spelling in the Tibetan field, but only the archaic form appears in the Degé Kangyur, then you can add the archaic form as a second alternate Tibetan field.

Tibetan Transliterated Sanskrit: It is very important to always check terms containing transliterated Sanskrit, as very often these will not have been entered with correct extended Wylie. As extended-Wylie is very precise, if anything is entered incorrectly, it will create gobbledygook in the Tibetan Unicode field. Often the translator has not used proper Wylie at all, and so all of the transliterated terms will need to be re-entered from the eKangyur. (By the way, this is not ideal, the translator may have consulted the Pedurma or other Kangyur editions when corroborating the spelling of glossary terms; if they did this but did not use proper extended-Wylie then that corroborative research will have to be thrown out and we will need to fall back on the eKangyur--either that or ask the translator to redo it.) Note that the easiest and laziest way to assure the extended-Wylie is correct is to paste the Tibetan Unicode into the THLib transliteration app. It's good to forward this to any translators or editors that may be unaware.

item.label: Method 2: Check Mismatching Tibetan with a Python Script

list.item: Particularly with a large glossary, you might not have time to check every instance in the Glossary Editor, especially if there is lag. Another option is to use this python script which will check every <term xml:lang="bo"> against the Degé eKangyur and give you a list of any string that doesn't match anywhere in that specific eKangyur text.
To run this script please follow the instructions in the following github repository: Glossary Checker

This python script is useful but it is not fail proof. Some terms may not match because an alternate Kangyur recension was used for the glossary field. Be vigilant against terms that are missing a letter at the very beginning or end of a string; for instance "སྐལ་བཟང" will not be flagged if it is actually "སྐལ་བཟངས" and just missing the final ས letter.

There are indeed some errors in the eKangyur. If you see suspicious spelling or a singular transliterated Sanskrit term in the eKangyur it may be good to occasionally check. Use the Dege Scan Checking script here. If you notice an error please report it in the spreadsheet here.
Delete Tibetan Field: Remember to delete Tibetan Unicode field after making a correction to the Wylie field. Otherwise the Tibetan Unicode will not be regenerated and the error will remain.

div.head: Mark the Glossary as Verified:

list.item: We have just begun the step of marking the glossary as "verified" if we have completely checked all the Tibetan spellings in the glossary. If you have done this with the python script, or by checking each and every entry in the Glossary Editor, go ahead and add @status="verified" to each and every <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> field e.g. shA ri’i bu Apply this to the Wylie field. You can do this by searching for: <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> and replacing with <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn" status="verified">

It is not absolutely necessary that the glossary be verified during markup. If because of time or other reasons a complete verification process could not be completed then forgo adding this "status" tag and move on to the next step.

div.p: At this point all the basic editing for the Glossary should be complete. However, there is still some work to be done regarding how the glossary terms are being linked within the text. However, this step is better done on step A.11 when you are going through and looking at the web display. This section will also refer you to Appendix C which explicitly define the guidelines for how the Glossary terms are to be linked in the Reading Room. However, don't worry about this yet, the guidelines will step you through that process when you reach that stage at A.11 below.

div.head: Add Optional Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit Chains
div.p: Next, optional soft-hyphens should be entered for any long Sanskrit chains. The guidelines for doing this are shown in the Appendix ().

div.head: Add Links For References (Both In-Text and External)

list.item: Create links for any references in the text, e.g., "see page ###" or "see Bibliography." Links for in-text references or references to other 84000 texts are created with the ptr element and external references to other web pages are created with the ref element. However, links to Kangyur/Tangyur texts that are not yet published should be marked with a ref tag with a @rend="pending" attribute. There are some detailed guidelines for entering cross references. Please see Appendix B.4: for further details.

It is also important to check the introduction and endnotes for any intext references to chapters or sections and add ptr tags anywhere the reader might want to follow a link. In the introduction the translator may have pointed out sections of the translation using Dege folio references; unless these mentions are specifically referring to the Tibetan source text or the structure thereof, these folio references should be changed to the milestone numbers generated in the Reading Room -- according to what can be referenced most conveniently by the reader.

div.head: Assign Shared Entities and Apply Standard Definitions

list.item: Through the glossary editor, assign shared entities to each glossary entry matching them to entities in the cumulative glossary or creating new ones for any new entities. The guidelines for this process can be found here in the google document, Guidelines for Shared Entities. While going through the shared entities, it is a good time to check the glossary definitions to see which terms should use the standard definition found in the shared entity.

The translator may have requested for some glossary entries to "use the standard definition" in the definition field. If this is the case apply the following:
(1) Match the entry to the shared entity
(2) Delete the definition field in the TEI or make sure it is completely blank (empty definitions will automatically display matched entity definitions)
(3) If any requested standard definitions are not yet created, send a list requested definitions to the Glossary Lead (André @andre.rodrigues@84000.co)
(4) If the standard definition is requested but there is also contextual information to be included before the standard definition, both may be displayed by opening the entry in the glossary editor, linking the entry to the appropriate entity and selecting as the definition status "Compatible".

List Definitions to be Updated: While going through the glossary and assigning entities, make a running list of glossary entries with definitions that could be better updated to use the standard definition. There are such cases where a there is a low quality definition like, "The Blessed One -- An epithet of the Buddha." which could be updated to the standard one which provides more detail and explanation. Then list these entries in the Reading Room Worksheet to be reviewed by the editor at the end. Alternatively, the list could be placed in a google doc and sent to the editor separately if the list is long and that is deemed to be more convenient.

div.p: Note that we are trying to limit the proliferation of redundant definitions in the cumulative glossary, so if you spot that the translator has copy and pasted the standard definition, it would be best to delete the definition and simply link to the standard one. Occasionally, the translator may have copied the standard definition but reworded some terminology. If this is the case, use your own judgement to determine if it is possible/appropriate to reduce this to contextual information as a supplement the standard definition.

div.head: See how the Text Looks on the Web Page

list.item: Go through the text again in web display, making sure everything looks okay.

item.p: Keep an Eye Out for Unwanted Blank Spaces. This is unfortunately an issue that occasionally occurs through the conversion scripts. It typically happens when multiple tags are set next to each other, such as the spaces between mantra tags and notes. Occasionally this will create an unwanted space that was not in the original Word doc. We are currently working on improving the scripts to resolve this and prevent these unwanted spaces from being generated, but in the meantime keep an eye out for extra spaces, particularly ones that appear after a foreign or mantra tag and before a note or punctuation.
For example see the unwanted spaces after the foreign term "mthong", and the ones before and after "khums" in the following example:
item.egXML: Here the imperative thong (“admit / release”), however, could easily be a scribal error for mthong , “behold.” KY, K, and N have the imperative “subsume!” ( khums ).

list.item: It is helpful at this point to put the web page in “editor mode.” This underlines the linked glossary terms for you. Otherwise, in the regular display, it underlines them but then they will disappear after a few seconds, which will be frustrating when your are checking the links. An additional benefit of editor mode is that all of the collapsed sections of the text (Intro, Translation, Notes, etc...) will be expanded by default, so that you can more easily search for terms in the web display with CTRL-F. To put the page in editor mode, simply add the following text to the end of the URL web address: ?view-mode=editor

At this point you should check to see that the glossary is linking to the right terms. In the summary and introduction in particular there may be many instances of a word linking to the glossary when it shouldn’t, for example in the phrase “in terms of…” the word “term” might link to the glossary for the technical meaning of “term”; or to take another example, in the phrase “with respect to…” the word “respect” might link to “respect” as in devotion (these are just two out of many examples). Note, the translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the “†” symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate". If they have done so then, don't leave these markers in the text, but replace them with the markup described in the following section. However, it is likely that a lot of these terms will be missed so you should also scan through the text in editor mode for any of these improperly linked terms.

Also check that the highlighted terms correspond to their definition given in the Glossary. For example, although term ཁམས་ can refer to the 18 dhatus, it can also sometimes refer to the 4 or 5 elements (earth, air, fire, water and space--although usually the term འབྱུང་པ་/པོ་ is used for this set). Both cases may be translated by the English word "element," but if the definition only mentions the 18 dhatus, then instances of the latter case of the 4 or 5 elements should not be linked.

To fix these instances add the term rend="ignore" tag to the ones that should not be linked. Optionally the mode attribute may be added to the gloss element in the glossary. If the mode is set to mode="match" (this is the default mode, by the way), you will be able to block strings in the text you don't want to link by marking them with this term rend="ignore" tag. If you change it to mode="marked", it will only link with strings in the text that are tagged with the term element (you will need to mark each instance of the term individually in this case).

In these cases you can save yourself some time when choosing between the "marked" or "match" modes. It is good to think about which mode will require the least amount of tags. Usually this will be the default "match" mode, but it varies from case to case.

In some cases there may be three or more glossary entries with the same word. For example, if three people in the text have the same name. In this case, the instances may be distinguished using mode="marked" and adding @ref ids to all the instances of that name marked with a term element. Please see Appendix C for details and examples of this.

If there are any instances in the web display where there is a term in the glossary that is showing "0 instances in this text" (in the right-hand column of the glossary), you should find out if that term is actually in the text. There may be a spelling error, a diacritic error, or some other reason why it isn't linking to the glossary entry. Sometimes there is a glossary term that really isn't in the text (possibly because it was in the introduction and later removed). If this is the case make a note about it in the final list of questions and issues to address when you have finished the text.

There are several subtle points for polishing the final glossary. In some cases alternatives may need to be added to link particular terms and in some cases the glossary terms will need to be checked against the original Tibetan. So we have created a separate Appendix C that explains how the glossary works, along with a few further tips for editing it. Please take a look at Appendix C here.

div.head: Final Details
div.p: A few final things to look out for while going through your final run of the text:

list.item: Double check links and make sure they go to the right places.

Check the long title, main title in the translation, and title in trailer; check the use of the terms "Mahāyāna" vs. "Great Vehicle" is this consistent? It's fine if varying terms are used in the notes and introduction but these instances in the translation itself should be consistent.

In the colophon, mkhan po should be translated as "preceptor" or "upādhyāya", but not as "teacher," "scholar," or "paṇḍita" (although careful, sometimes it does say paNDi ta in the source, in which case it is okay). Note that the translators often replicate this in the introduction.

div.p: Final Checks Using Regular Expression (Use the regular search menu and check "Regular expression"):

item.p: Make sure links aren't missing. Sometimes if the hashtag "#" is missing or misplaced in the "target" attribute in the ptrs then the reference won't appear at all and you will see text like "(see above, .)" without anything coming after it. Search for any instance of these using the regex pattern:

Check folio refs inside mantras. There is currently a rare bug where if there is a folio reference, e.g., <ref type="folio"/> inside a mantra element and that element is flush with the preceding p element, then the folio ref will not link in the reading room. For example:

In this example the folio reference F.102.a will not display the eKangyur when it is clicked in the reading room. In this rare situation where they are directly next to each other (if there is any characters between them like a quote mark, space, or letter this problem doesn't occur), the fix for this is to simply put a single line break between the p and mantra. So from the example above:

(This is a line break in the XML itself NOT an lb element). This will not alter the text in anyway as it appears in the reading room but it will fix the broken link for F.102.a to the eKangyur. To search for this issue you can simple search with this regular expression:

This will find any mantras flush against the p element, and you can add the line break or just ignore it if there is no refs inside the mantra. This is an issue that you should check if there are any formatted mantras in the text. Eventually we will bring this up with eXist to fix this bug, but in the meantime this should be checked like this at the end of markup.

For any links created with the ref element be sure that none of the links were accidentally set to forward the reader to a page on collaboration or in one of the editor view modes. This can be checked by doing a simple search for "view-mode" and "read.84000-translate.org":

Check for empty tags (style tags that may have been accidentally left over a blank space in the Word template). The following pattern will search any tags that surround an empty space or non-breaking space:

Within the text's introduction and body notes should always be flush with the preceding character with no space between them. Occasionally, the note element may be separated by a linebreak in the XML when it is formatted or when it originally went through the script. To correct these instances you can search the regular expression:
and replace with

list.head: Search through the text and correct any erroneous straight apostrophes and quote marks. Note that the translator guidelines says to use typographical apostrophes and quote marks (‘ ’ “ ”) not straight ones (' "). All Wylie Tibetan transliteration of the a-chung character should use a right-curling apostrophe ’ not a left-curling one. One exception to this rule is for strings of Sanskrit transliteration which may use a straight apostrophe ' to represent the avagraha character; this is allowed so long as it is done consistently. Otherwise straight apostrophes should be avoided unless there is some pertinent reason to include them. These straight apostrophes and quotes are easy to miss and often can slip unnoticed into our publications, so please run the following searches before submitting your final markup:
list.item: (1) Check for straight apostrophes ' : This is easily done with a search-and-replace command for the ' character. Just make sure you check each one, most of them will need to be replaced with right-curling apostrophes but some will need to be replaced with a left-curling one.

(2) Check for straight double quote marks " : This is a little trickier as straight quote marks are used in the XML tags. To find them in the text and ignore all the tags open the CTRL/SHIFT/H, select "All open files" in the scope and search for the straight double quote " but in the field that says "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code //text() this will search for the straight double quote only in the text but not the tags.
(3) Check for left-curling apostrophe in Wylie Transliteration: Again use the XPath/XQuery and search for //*[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(data(), "‘")]

(4) Occasionally the unicode for a "modified word apostrophe" (U+02BC) may have been entered into the document. These look identical in the Oxygen editor and in most fonts in general. However they display inconsistently with each other in the Reading Room and can interfere with data searches in the Tibetan Wylie. Since this unicode has been depreciated in most word processors it is unlikely to occur, but you should check for any (U+02BC)s by searching the following character: ʼ and all of these should be replaced with right curling single quote marks (U+2019), which you can paste using this character here: ’ (They look the same but they are not. Notice with the Unicode identifier at the bottom of the screen in Oxygen)

Address any final schema errors. Occasionally, the schema may need to be updated to accommodate a new type of formatting. Or, if a note uses a term in a language that hasn't been used in a published text yet, then that ISO 639-1 code may need to be added to the schema. In either case contact me about this (Celso) and I will add adjust the schema as needed.
If the text is a large or complex text, it may be a good idea to check the original .DOCX for any "hidden" text. See Appendix .
Note any formatting or style issues that look wrong or awkward.
Make note of any grammar or editing errors that you think may have been missed in the copy editing phase. You can also add this to your final list of questions and issues.

We have created a googlesheet to post and track any irregularities/inconsistencies between texts that may be a cause for concern. This is principally shared between the copy editors, but markup should feel free to report any issues that may be noticed in the markup process here: Irregularities in Published Translations.

Run Automated Tests from Utilities
As a final step run the series of automated tests from the Translations Tab on the Utilities Page. You will find a link next to the text title that says "Run tests". Note these are the same tests that are performed from the "Tests" tab, but this "Run tests" link only performs them on the individual text (running tests on all the texts at once uses a lot of the server's resources so this should only be done when testing global updates). It the server will perform a series of tests and display the results. If any of the tests fail, click on that entry and it should display the explanation for the error. Most of these you should be able to resolve, but on occasion there may be an error that is difficult to diagnose or sometimes there is a unique anomaly causing the error and the test itself needs to be updated. In either case please notify the lead tech (dominic.latham@84000.co) about any of the test failures that can't be resolved.

div.head: Request Sanskrit Review and List any Outstanding Issues from the Reading Room Worksheet
Request an Editor to Check the Sanskrit terms in the Glossary
div.p: At some point the glossary should be checked by an editor who has a qualified knowledge of Sanskrit. Currently our go to is Wiesiek Mical (@wiesiek@84000.co) or Ryan Damron (@rdamron@84000.co). There are some project editors who are also sufficient with Sanskrit (David Fiordalis and Torston Gerloff) and a Sanskrit check will not be necessary if it is confirmed that the glossary has been checked by a qualified editor. Otherwise, please send Wiesiek (or Ryan if Wiesiek is unavailable) an email asking them to review the Sanskrit terms in the glossary once it is up on Collaboration. Please cc editorial and the project editor in this email, as they should approve any changes that are needed to the Sanskrit glossary. That is to say send an email to the Sanskrit reviewer at the same time you request the project editor to review the outstanding issues in the RRWorksheet.

Mark Sanskrit as Verified: If the Sanskrit is successfully verified, then as with the Tibetan terms, this should be marked in the TEI if time permits. Ideally, the Sanskrit check can be completed and all the terms can be updated at once with a search and replace searching for: term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn" and replacing with term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn" status="verified"

div.head: Post Final Issues in the Reading Room Worksheet

list.item: As you work on the text, make a running list of any problems or issues that you cannot fix yourself and make this into a final list of questions and issues. There are often a lot of things that come up: some of them should be addressed by the project editor. This list should be pasted into the Reading Room Revisions spreadsheet, which you can access through this link. There are several sheets within this document. Use the sheet entitled "Texts in Markup" and create a new heading for the text you are working on. There are also workflow instructions for how to post issues within the Reading Room Worksheet itself, at the very top of the first sheet under the "In Markup" tab.

You may find solutions to these issues as you go, and if you just need your solutions or corrections to be checked by one of the editors, then assign the first "status" column with the orange label "check". Otherwise assign any new issues as "new".

Most issues should be resolved by the project editor. However, should any technical or copyediting issues arise, then from the "Pending on" column you can assign this issue to the appropriate party to check:
Any copyeditor issues (spelling, grammar, and style issues) may be assigned to Laura (laura.goetz@84000.co), Konchog (konchog@84000.co), or Dion (dionandon@gmail.com).
If the schema needs to be updated or there are markup issues, a new element or value (e.g., xml:lang) needs to be validated, assign the issue to Celso (celso.wilkinson@84000.co).
For more technical issues to do with the parser or file generation, assign the problem to Dom (dominic.latham@84000.co)
In general we want to avoid burdening the editorial directors (John and Andreas), with editorial problems that could be resolved by the project editors, but sometimes there may be some important issues that require a directorial decision. In such cases, first check with the manager of publications, Mike (mike.engle@84000.co) and he will forward such issues to the directors as is necessary.

When all the issues are listed in the RRWorksheet please email the project editor letting them know that the first round of markup is done, and you are ready for them to review the final issues in the worksheet. Please cc editorial@84000.co.

At this point if you haven't had the Sanskrit glossary reviewed during step A.7.4, you should also send an email request to an editor with qualified Sanskrit expertise (Wiesiek or Ryan) to review the glossary. Please cc the project editor here as well for approval.

As mentioned in the sheet's workflow instructions, you can assign issues to specific parties by making a comment and typing the "@" or "+" character, then selecting them from a drop down list. Or, if you prefer it's fine to just email that person directly. It's best to give a suggestion for how the issue may be resolved either from the "comments" column or by email if necessary.

Occasionally, for issues that everyone may want to discuss, you can also notify or email one of the departments as a whole with the following groups:
84000-markup-editors@googlegroups.com -- address all markup.
84000-copyeditors@googlegroups.com -- all copyeditors.
all_editors@84000.co -- addresses all project editors (cc's John and Andreas for overview).

As these issues are resolved please clean up your text's section in the review sheet. For anything that is fully resolved you can mark its status as "archive" and move it to the "resolved archive" sheet (or just delete it if it is inconsequential). If it seems to be an issue that may come up again and may be useful to reference in the future, you can also add it to the "reference archive" sheet.

When all the final issues have been resolved or noted for the final review in the Reading Room Worksheet, notify the lead markup editor; the markup will be reviewed one more time them and then they will update the status to "2", ("Markup Completed, and awaiting final proofing before release").

If there are any parts of this TEI editor's checklist that need to be clarified or updated you can contact Celso to make those updates. You can either assign the task to him on the Reading Room Worksheet or email him at celso.wilkinson@gmail.com.

div.head: Final Review by Editor in Hypothesis

list.item: Post to Hypothesis and let editor know it is ready for final review. Please see Hypothesis instructions from this link: Hypothesis Instructions on Google Drive

Apply the editor's final changes from hypothesis annotations. After applying the changes, email the editor and ask them to take a final look; if they say it looks good, proceed to publishing the text.

div.head: Publication
div.p: When it's time to publish the text:

list.item: The mark-up editor takes a final review of the text before pushing to distribution. Once they deem it is ready, they enter into "Edit Headers" in Project Management for the specific text. The mark-up editor then changes the text status to "1a" (it's been published, but not yet in the app); adds the correct publication date to the current date; changes the version number to 1.0.0; adds “First published version” under the “Note about this version”; and under “Progress Notes” writes “First published November 11 2021” for example. The markup editor then presses update to save all of those changes.
Markup should now run the automated tests from utilities (just for that single text, don't run the tests for all the texts)

Be sure the cache is updated to the latest version, otherwise click on "generate new cache (glossary tool)" from project management. This is important for the epub and pdf to cache the glossary and notes properly.

The markup editor then selects the option in Project Management “Generate associated files” to generate the pdf and ebook files subsequently checking they were properly generated notifying Dom of any issues. This involves manually checking each file generated to make sure they layout and formatting is correct. They also regenerate the cache using the link in Edit Headers.

Once the files are correctly generated the markup editor should go to the utilities app on the distribution server (https://utilities.84000.co/translations.html). Search for the text by Toh number. Now click on "Get all updated files", this will push the publication to distribution.

Take a look at the text on distribution and check to make sure the text is displaying correctly and is readable. For most texts this check can be pretty quick, but if there was any unusual formatting in the text, e.g. tables, irregular folio mapping, complex divisions; please check these as well in the reading room and various file formats to make sure that everything is generating properly.

Announce that the text has been published on the Whatsapp group "84000 editorial team"--please also provide a link to the published text. The publication is now completed in terms of the markup editors responsibilities. From here, Line will see that the text has been published according to the whatsapp announcement and Line will prepare the text for public announcement.

As a last step, on the Jira board, please move the card for that text from the "In Review" column to the "Pre-Release" column. Assign the card to the glossary lead (André) who will then proceed to do a final review of the integration of the text's glossary with the cumulative glossary. When the glossary is integrated, the glossary lead will remove the @status="excluded" from the glossary (div element) and update the version to activate the integration. The glossary lead will then move the Jira card to "Released".

div.head: Italics, Bold, and Other Font styles.
div.label: Italics
div.p: In a given text, words or phrases may be italicized for different reasons. The need to express both presentation information (that text is italicized) as well as the semantic information about why it is italicized must be addressed. That is why instead of simply using the hi element, for example, the voices below form the markup menu for text that needs to be italicized:

list.item: distinct terms, words, or phrases singled out (in any language, but use this only when a "foreign" tag is not applicable).
emph words or phrases italicized for emphasis or rhetorical effect.
foreign xml:lang="" foreign words or phrases in any language.
foreign type="term" xml:lang="" a foreign term or phrase other than a quote or title, such as a term or phrase in parentheses following its translation, or a foreign term or phrase left untranslated.
title xml:lang="" title of a work (in any language).
foreign xml:lang="__-Ltn" Wylie or other type of Roman transliteration (excluding European languages, which should not have the "-Ltn" appendage).
foreign type="quote" xml:lang="" quotations from other texts.

mantra should be used to italicize complete mantras, however this is a bit more complex because some parts of mantras maybe translated into English. See Appendix B.6 for more about how to markup mantras.

div.p: Note that sometimes there may be some overlap between what distinguishes the italics tag used for a “term” vs. a “quote.” In such cases you can use your own discretion, but in general italics used for a “term” are for specific a word or phrase that is left un-translated usually because it is technical, untranslatable, or for some other reason. In contrast the italics used for a “quote” are for italics used for a word or phrase citing a specific instance in a source text either to corroborate the English translation, or to note some difference between two or more sources. Both tags are rendered the same in the end, so this isn’t a critical call to make. There is no need spend time looking up italics to determine whether or not they are found in sources, but just keep this general principle in mind when distinguishing the proper tag for italics.

Note that Tibetan script and Chinese characters should be given the xml:lang value of "bo" and "zh" respectively, while Tibetan, Chinese, and Sanskrit romanized transliteration should have the values of "Bo-Ltn," "Zh-Ltn," and "Sa-Ltn" respectively. For other languages use the list of ISO 639-1 codes to find the appropriate xml:lang value. Most often an Asian language will be translated into the Roman script and, therefore, the first letter of the ISO 639-1 code should be capitalized followed by "-Ltn". Thus a Thai term "th" in Romanized script should be coded "Th-Ltn." If the term is a European language or the native script of that language is used, then use the two letter code as usual, e.g., "fr" (French), "la" (Latin), etc.

For the most part, these tags should be added during the copy editing phase in the 84000 Template.docx. In this phase they will be added as styles in MS Word, but will be transformed into the appropriate tag by our scripts. However, as we can't add a style for every language in the template, the markup editor will need look up and edit the tags for any uncommon languages, which will be marked through the script as xml:lang="Input Language." The markup editor should also keep an eye out for errors, or italicized text that was missed. However, the script should render all unmarked italics with a "<fix>" tag, which will be highlighted as an error by the schema.
div.label: Bold, Underline, and Other Font Styles
div.p: We typically don't use bold and underline very often, but they may be necessary for various semantic reasons:

list.item: The label element, will render text bold, but this should be used only for labels in lists or outlines. Otherwise,
Use the hi element to add "bold", "underline", "line-through", "small-caps", "superscript", or "subscript" as the @rend value to change the font style as needed.
The emph element can also take a @rend attribute to add "bold", "underline", or "line-through" in combination with italics, which emph renders by default.
See examples in the layout checks here.

div.head: Types of Divisions
div.p: Div elements are used to mark different sections within a text. This is of particular importance as the head tag can only follow directly after a "div" marker or another head tag. The main sections of the text are marked as follows:

list.item: div type="summary" Wraps the Summary section.
div type="acknowledgement" Wraps the Acknowledgement section.
div type="prologue" Wraps the Prologue (if there is one).
div type="preface" Wraps the Preface (if there is one).
div type="introduction" Wraps the Introduction.
div type="translation" Wraps the entire translation.
div type="notes" Wraps the notes section; this section is needed for displaying abbreviations.
div type="listBibl" Contains a group of bibl elements, wraps the bibliography.
div type="appendix" To wrap the appendix of a text, e.g. a Sanskrit Appendix (if there is one).
div type="colophon" Wraps the colophon. (Note, the schema only allows this nested as a second level div after all second level "sections" and/or "chapters")

div.p: Within those major document units or divisions, there are other sub units, especially chapters or their equivalent. Both chapter and section refer to the same hierarchical level in the XML. Chapters are the type value used in the body of the text when they have been specified as chapters by the translator. Section is used for equivalent level sectioning that has not been called a chapter. Examples for the latter are sectioned bibliographies, where the whole of the bibliography has multiple sections organized by source type. In that case div type="section" is used instead of div type="chapter". From a structural point of view, however, they are the same.

list.item: div type="chapter" Wraps a chapter that is part of the translation.
div type="section" Wraps a section of the TEI document.

div.head: Outlines and Lists
div.p: Sometimes the introduction of a text will provide an outline, particularly in the case of a longer or more complicated text. Within the TEI XML these outlines should be constructed using the list and item elements. For a complex outline with many levels of subsections, the outline itself should be contained in a list, and each section should be contained in an item within that list. Then, for each sub section, a new list element should be nested within those items, which in turn contains its own subsections with item elements, and so forth for as many subsections as necessary. Note that if the list is marked up as type="bullet" it will be indented. A good way to render the outline in a clear way is to mark up the first list as type="section" and all subsequent lists as type="bullet"; then the major sections will be separated by vertical spacing and all the subsections will be indented. For an example see the following outline from "The Baskets Display" (Toh 116): The XML markup from this outline in Toh. 116 is shown below.

item.p: I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery when lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and then the city of the pretas.

1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama and describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and praises him.
II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell.
1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells, visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This very sūtra sounds in their realm.

div.p: This will allow the outline to be properly displayed in the 84000 reading room. For more simple outlines that have a one-level list, use the list with type="bullet" if the items are one or two sentences long (for an example, see Toh. 11 here), and use type="section" if the items are longer sections of text (see also Toh. 11 here). The "bullet" and "section" types can be used in alternation however they are needed, just note that "section" will have vertical spacing between each item, and "bullet" will be indented.

The head element resting within the list tag, but outside of the item tag can be used to create a bold heading at the top of a list. Alternatively, within an item tag a label attribute may be used to the same effect. See Toh. 11 again for an example, along with the following XML markup from that same section:

list.head: I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA
list.p: The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized. Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters, with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10.

item.label: Chapters 1 and 2
item.p: In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection of wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is the absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative experiences, all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional attributes manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including omniscience. along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of all things and the finality of existence, these are all attributes with respect to which a great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment. Bodhisattvas do perceive such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative level; in an ultimate sense they consider them to be illusory, in the manner of a dream and so forth.

item.label: Chapter 3
item.p: Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are considered as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or suffering, with self or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or signless, having or lacking aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void, afflicted or purified, arising or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as entities or non-entities. Deluded minds would view these phenomena and attributes as absolutely existent whereas bodhisattvas should train so as to understand that they are all non-apprehensible—mere designations and conceptualizations.

item.p: The name tshe dpag tu med pa (Aparimitāyus), which occurs a number of times here in Toh 674, is given its longer form in Toh 675: tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa (Aparimitāyur­jñāna).

The name of Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s realm here in Toh 674 is yon tan dpag tu med pa sogs pa (Aparimita­guṇa­saṃcaya, “Accumulation of Immeasurable Qualities”), but in Toh 675 the first mention of it is just yon tan dpag tu med pa (Aparimitaguṇa, “Immeasurable Qualities”).

div.p: Note that lists along with their items can be generated from the template .docx passed through our XSLT script. In MS Word, lists are auto-generated either by clicking the list icons on the menu bar or by entering a "1" or "*" and on a new line and hitting the space key. These lists will be rendered by the XSLT script with nested list and item tags. It can render multi-leveled lists or outlines, however they need to be auto-generated list in MS Word for them to pass through the script; you can determine that they are auto-generated when in MS Word the cursor will skip over the bullet point or numbered prefix of the list when passed across with the arrow keys. The first level list will be tagged type="bullet" by default, but second level lists and beyond will need the type attribute to be entered manually.

item.label: Milestones:
item.p: Cross references in the text that refer to milestones will be added using a ptr element with the "target" attribute. The value of the target should be a hashmark ("#") followed by the xml:id value of the milestone that is to be linked. For example: See . The milestone number as it appears on the web page may be listed as a comment afterwards, but it should not be entered as text as the parser will automatically show the milestone number in the web display. This way even if the milestones shift around it will still display and link to the correct milestone on the web page.

One important point about adding references to the introduction: When you mark up introductions with internal ptr references to the translation, replace any Degé folio references (e.g F.108.a) with milestone references. For most readers that will make much more sense. Of course the translators have no choice, because at the time they put such cross-references in there are no milestones.

If you can’t identify exactly the passage and its milestone, you can leave it as the folio reference, and ask the editors to make the change during the final proofing. And, of course, if the reference is really all (and only) about a Tibetan passage in the source text, and the translation is irrelevant, a folio reference makes more sense.

item.p: When another Kangyur/Tengyur text is referenced that has not yet been published, the editors have been instructed to enter a coded comment in the form: <Reference Toh ####>, sometimes with the folio reference added when it is specified. Of course, you should check to see if the text has been published in the meantime, but if it is still pending, then we should mark the link with a ref tag containing the @rend="pending" attribute. This will suppress the link making it inactive, but it will be flagged by our apps when the text is published. However it is important that the correct URL for the unpublished text is entered in the @target attribute so that our apps will pick it up. The URL will follow this form https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER TOH NUMBER HERE].html. This is the format to use for all general links to unpublished texts, in which the link will eventually open to the title page of the texts. However, in cases where a specific section of that text is mentioned, which should usually indicated by a folio page reference, the folio reference or other instruction for locating the specitic citation should be added to the ref tag in an @inst attribute. div.p: Occasionally translators may present a table in their translation. Tables can be used anywhere in the text or even contained within an endnote. The XSL script should be equipped to convert tables from the DOCX document to the TEI XML; however, attributes need to be applied to the tables, rows, and cells manually (see for example the role="label" attributes found in the rows in the XML sample below). Also each table should be checked against the original DOCX to assure that there weren't any errors in the conversion process. So far there have note been many tables in 84000 publications but here is one example from TOH 361:

div.p: As you can see a table contains an optional heading and a series of rows. Each row in turn contains a series of cells representing the way they are to be rendered from left to right. Add the very bottom of the table after the final row, any notes may be placed here regarding the table itself. In the example above there are three such notes marked by asterisks. These are not endnotes, as they do not have the place="end" attribute, so they will be rendered at the bottom of the table rather than becoming additional endnotes. Optionally, paragraphs p may be placed at the bottom of the table in a similar manner, still within the table but after the final row.

Currently there is no need to distinguish how the table should be rendered, but as this becomes necessary, any rendition information should be supplied using the global rend attribute, at the table, row, or cell level as appropriate. Currently no type is being used, but this may be added to the schema and documentation when it becomes necessary. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent cells are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a row contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child cells will be considered to be "label"s as well. These labels will be rendered in bold type in the HTML web display.

Note, when marking up tables the markup editor should check that the table renders properly in the reading room's web display. In addition, the table needs to be checked in the ebook display as well. This can be done by adding the code: ?viewmode=epub to the very end of the url address on the utilities page. In truth, the tables are not compatible with the ebook format, so the parser will instead display them as a bulleted list. The information in this list should be presented in a complete and eloquently readable way, otherwise the parser should be updated.

div.head: Mantras
div.label: Documenting all mantras with mantra tags.

p.hi: *** Important note: Every mantra should be tagged with a mantra tag. The @rend="manta" in the parent p or lg element does not count as a mantra tag; it only functions to indent the paragraph for a mantra that is set apart as its own paragraph.

div.p: The purpose of the mantra tag itself is two-fold: (1) We want to document every complete instance of a mantra for our database, and (2) the mantra tag will create italics for mantras that are left in their original language and not translated into English. However, occasionally there will be mixed mantras (xml:lang="mixed"), which partially translated into English with leftover fragments of foreign italicized terms in the form of seed syllables or untranslatable words (Hung! Phet! etc...). Therefore, the italics will be generated by the parser according to the xml:lang attributes in the mantra element: if the value is "en" or "mixed" the mantra won't be italicized, but with any other language value all the text within the mantra tag will be italicized. In the case of a mixed translated English/Sanskrit mantra, the Sanskrit fragments within the parent mantra need to be additionally marked up with <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn"> elements in order to render the italics. See examples below in "a. General Scenarios."
div.label: Tagging mantras with styles in MS Word
div.p: To help stream line this process the mantras will be partially marked up by styles converted from the copyeditor template in MS Word, however because MS Word can't layer multiple character styles, we can't tag the foreign fragments and the mantras at the same time. To resolve this conundrum, we have come up with the following solution: If the mantra is full and complete in one language, it can be tagged with the appropriate style in the template, but if the mantra is mixed, then just the italicized fragments should be tagged with a "Fragment-in-MixedMantra" style. This will in turn create a foreign element that contains a type="FragmentinMixedMantra" attribute. Then since "FragmentinMixedMantra" is not a valid type value in our schema it will show up as an error, which will signal you to wrap the whole mantra in a <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tag. Finally after these mixed mantras have been wrapped in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tags from their beginning to end, all of the type="FragmentinMixedMantra" attributes can be removed with the refactoring tool: Within the Tools --> XML Refactoring tool, use the "Delete Attribute" opperation, then for element enter in: mantra/foreign[@type="FragmentinMixedMantra"] and for the attribute enter in: type This will insure that only the type attributes will be removed that have the value "FragmentinMixedMantra" and it will also only remove those of foreign elements within mantras, this way it will ensure that all of them have first been properly wrapped in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> elements.
div.label: Placing some mantras in indented blocks.
div.p: In terms of style, whenever there is a formally declared mantra, it will often be placed into an indented block paragraph. This is not configured by the mantra tag, but rather by adding a rend="mantra" attribute to the parent p or lg element which is to be rendered as an indented block by the parser. However, this will not always the case, depending on the length, frequency, and context of the mantra, the translator and/or copy editors may wish to place the mantras in regular paragraphs or verses. This is a stylistic choice that will vary from case to case. All of the rend="mantra" attributes will be created by the script wherever the "Mantra-Block" or "Mantra-Block-Verse" paragraph style is used within the copyeditor's template. So in general, this will be dealt with in the copyediting phase and markup editors will not need to apply these rend attributes, but you should be aware how this markup works.
div.label: Dhāraṇis and seed syllables.
div.p: Seed syllables that are mentioned in the text for the purposes of visualization or explanation should also be marked up as mantras, but they need to be distinguished with the type="syllable" attribute (see example below a.iv).

For all dhāraṇis, that is if a string or phrase is declared to be a dhāraṇi by either the text itself or the translator, then these should be tagged in the same way, but a type="dharani" attribute should be added to the mantra element. Currently "dhāraṇi" styles have not been added to the template, instead copy editors are informed to make a comment whenever dharanis are present. The markup editor need to add the appropriate type="dharani" so be sure to keep an eye out for this while going through the mantras in the XML. There are also some mantras self described as "vidyā", "vidyāmantra", "secret mantra", etc. in some texts (see Toh 270, 543) which can be tagged in the same way.
See below examples for all the scenarios in which mantra markup occurs and how to properly mark them up:
div.label: a. General Scenarios:

item.p: i. When the complete mantra in Sanskrit is contained in the main text:

lg.l: “There are mantra syllables for this,
So please listen to me, Lord of the World!

item.p:
*mantra tag will be italicized by parser.
*rend attribute in the parent p or lg will determine if the mantra is indented as a block.

item.p: ii. When there is mixed translated English/Sanskrit mantra with a note that contains the complete mantra in Sanskrit:

*Mixed mantra is placed in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tags (need to be applied by markup editor since MS Word can't double wrap tags).
*Note, the language values that are included in xml:lang=“mixed” are all declared by its child foreign elements with the exception of the default “en” English.
*Italics will be determined by the foreign tags and not the parent mantra tag.
*Any left over type="FragmentinMixedMantra" tags are to be removed with the refactoring tool after completing mantra markup.

lg.l: “He should visualize a sun disk
With blazing light rays,
And at its center the syllable hrīḥ,
Shining with red light. {2.4.15}

item.p: note. In general, with English/mixed mantras we should include the final period or exclamation mark within the tag, as the mantra is usually a complete sentence and sometimes spans more than one sentences so it makes sense to include them for consistency. However, if the mantra is entirely in Sanskrit, then this punctuation should be excluded if possible. Quotations at the boundaries of the mantra should be excluded from the tag wherever possible.
