div.label: e. Blocking glossary terms from linking to Sanskrit/foreign mantras.
div.p: Optionally a @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribut may be added to any mantra element. Typically we want to do this for any Mantra left in untranslated Sanskrit since the complex spelling declinations will cause the terms to be linked inconsistently. However it is likely appropriate to leave such terms linked when the mantra has been translated into English. Know that in either case, @rend="ignoreGlossary" will block the entire mantra from linking; or terms can instead be blocked individually by adding <term rend="ignore"> tags.
div.label: f. Regarding Homages
div.p: Typically, the homage preceding just before a mantra should not be included in the mantra tag nor the indented paragraph. This can sometimes be confusing since separate homages sometimes appear as part of the mantra proper. All of this should be worked out earlier in the workflow by the editors and copy editors, but in case you need to confirm this, here are some guidelines concerning the mantras and their homages given by Wiesiek Mical:
Most of the time there is no ambiguity. There are three things to look for when deciding whether the homage is part of the mantra or not, each of the three usually sufficient on its own to decide:

list.item:
1) The presence of tadyathā. If it is there, then the homage that precedes it is not part of the mantra, as in this mantra of Mahāśvetā (all examples quoted below are from the Mañjuśrīmūlakalpa):
Sanskrit Source:
namaḥ samantabuddhānām acintyādbhutarūpiṇām / tadyathā / oṁ śvete śrīvapuḥ svāhā //
In Translation:
Homage to all the buddhas whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The [vidyā] is:
<mantra>Oṁ, you with the white splendorous body! Svāhā!</mantra>
“Homage to all the buddhas,
Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable!
The next vidyā is:
“ Oṁ, you with the white, splendorous body! Svāhā!
See in Reading Room

2) But the tadyathā is not always there, as in this heart mantra of Mañjuśrī:
Sanskrit Source
namaḥ sarvabuddhānām / oṁ maṁ //
In Translation
“Homage be to all the buddhas!
<mantra>Oṁ maṁ!</mantra>
“Homage to all the buddhas!
“Oṁ maṁ!”
See in Reading Room It is almost a rule (exceptions are few) that the homage begins with namaḥ, and the mantra that follows it begins with oṁ, so the oṁ will usually marks the beginning of the mantra.

3) The third criterion to go by is that the homage addresses the buddhas (or the buddhas and bodhisattvas) in general, whereas the mantra addresses the deity—both examples given above make this clear, even though, in the second, Mañjuśrī is not addressed by name.
The above three criteria may be used to decide that the homage is not part of the mantra. So how to know when the homage is part of the mantra?
The main criterion is that the homage in such cases will typically begin with oṁ and address specifically the deity of the mantra (not the buddhas in general). This is illustrated by the example quoted by Celso—Oṁ, homage to Cakravartin, the invincible uṣṇīṣa of the tathāgatas, invisible at the top of their head, (oṁ namo • apratihata­tathāgatoṣṇīṣāya • anavalokita­mūrdhni cakra­varti)—where the homage addresses the uṣṇīṣa king Cakravartin, i.e. the deity that this mantra is invoking. The homage is therefore part of the mantra.
Even if the oṁ is missing (due to textual corruptions?), if the homage specifically addresses the deity, it still should be treated as part of the mantra:
Sanskrit Source
namo bhagavate • apratihatoṣṇīṣāya / ehi ehi bhagavan dharmarāja / pratīccheyam arghyaṃ… //
In Translation
<mantra>Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come, o blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome-offering… </mantra>
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come, O blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome offering of water, fragrances, flowers, incense, refreshments, and lamps, and protect me! Svāhā to you, one of invincible strength and power!
See in Reading Room Also, there are innumerable mantras that consist entirely of homage. In these cases, the presence or absence of oṁ is often the only differentiator between a mantra and just homage. For example, oṁ namaḥ śivāya is a mantra, and namaḥ śivāya on its own would by just homage.

Ellipses: Previously ellipses were made with three periods and non-breaking spaces (U+00A0) before each of the periods. However, we have updated our standard to instead use a single Unicode ellipsis character: … There is occasionally some ambiguity as to whether punctuation coming before/after an ellipsis should have a space; documentation for how to determine the proper standard for such punctuation is found here.
Soft Hyphen: See guidelines for soft hyphens in Appendix E: .

div.head: Abbreviations Section
div.p: As for when Kangyur abbreviations should be used here is a note from John:
I see this as needing an adapted approach, depending on the number and kind of notes, in several steps:

list.item: 1) I think in texts where there aren’t many notes about variants in different Kangyurs — let’s say a maximum of about 10 notes — it's probably easier for our readers if we simply spell out “Degé Kangyur” or “Stok Palace Kangyur” each time.

2) If there are more notes than that, but they almost all refer to one Kangyur, we could say “Degé Kangyur” the first time and just “Degé” in subsequent mentions, and an abbreviations list is unnecessary.

3) If there are quite a lot of notes and they refer to several different Kangyurs, or the Chinese, Sanskrit versions, etc., then we should definitely have an abbreviations list and use the sigla alone in all such notes.

div.p: This should be covered by the editors, but they may not have created an abbreviations section. If there are a lot for sigla used in the notes (situation 3 above), but there is not abbreviations section, then please create one modeled on other texts.
When the abbreviations for alternative Kangyur editions are used, you should follow the Vienna system.
Sigla with supscript letters should use the <hi rend="subscript"> tag, using the matching case used in the official sigla, e.g., KY .

div.head: Appendices--Sanskrit and Other Appendices
div.p: The headings, head, are used in the same manner as within the body of the text, and use the same possible @type attributes as is appropriate to the content, e.g., "prologue", "chapter", "section", etc.

The headings will appear in the table of contents and should be clearly labeled according to what they are ("Sanskrit Text", "An Outline of the Present Day Ordination Rite", etc.) so they can be easily found and referenced by the reader from the table of contents.
Here is an example from Toh 381:

p.tei:ref: See Toh 381 in Reading Room.

list.item: If it is a Sanskrit Appendix the initial heading should be labeled "Sanskrit Text" and then any sub headings may be labeled appropriately as chapters, sections, etc.
To distinguish between the numbers in the appendix's chapter headers from those in the main translation add an "-A" to each number, e.g., "Chapter A1", "Chapter A2"...

Often the translator will have typed untagged milestones into the Sanskrit appendices. If possible we would like to arrange our own milestones so that the milestone index generated in the reading room by the parser match up with these, and then the original milestones from the word doc may be commented out. For example see Toh 437, and if you look in the original TEI you will see the orginal milestones in the appendix have been commented out. However, there are some cases when this will not be possible because some complexity in the correlation. This was the case in Toh 543 where the text was translated from a Sanskrit manuscript in which chapters omitted in the Tibetan were skipped. In this case the final milestones were left in as is, and an explanation was added in the appendix's prologue.

Note, that often there will be entries in the glossary that may be Sanskrit names or terms that also appear in the Sanskrit appendix. However since these won't be linked consistently due to Sanskrit's complex spelling declinations, we generally want to avoid linking the Sanskrit body of the appendices all together. This can be done by adding an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute to either the p or div elements you would like to be blocked. Ostensibly there will be terms in the English prologue/introduction to the appendix that we would won't to link, so these @rend attributes can be applied and adjusted according to the need.

div.head: Keys: Using the @Key attribute to distinguish the content in duplicate texts with separate Toh numbers
div.p: Most elements allow for the key attribute: head, title, ref, p, foreign, lg, l, and mantra elements currently allow for them in the schema. If needed we could enable a key attribute for any element except for note elements. These can be used to allow for content to appear in one version of a text but not another. The key corresponds to the key of the specific Toh version of the text, e.g. "toh999", which is defined for each Toh version in the sourceDesc.
Here is an overview for how and when to use the key attributes:

list.item:
With ref elements: This is used to simply provide the alternate folio number, which will link to the proper page of the eKangyur in the reading room. This is very common. E.g., at the beginning of Toh 729:
Homage to the Three Jewels!
Here F.222.a will display in Toh 729 and F.160.a will display in Toh 1001. [See in web display]

item.p: With title or head elements: Some texts are exactly or nearly the same but have different titles. For instance, compare Toh 1090 and Toh 1777. The titles are distinguished with @keys in titles in the titleStmt, sometimes in the intro, and in the head of the body of the text. Note that the Kangyur catalog in the 84000 reader, under each Toh number, it will display any titles that are found in the titleStmt with non-matching @keys as alternative titles for that text.

With elements showing actual variations in the body of the text: p, lg, l, foreign, or mantra: Occasionally, there will be entirely different content or omitted content found between two versions that editorial has decided should be displayed distinctly. For example there is an homage omitted in Toh 1090 1.1 but that is found in Toh 1777 1.1. Be mindful that any note inside a p that is excluded in one version will likewise be omitted in that version, but it can be replaced by adding a note to a separate p element matched to the other text(s). This was done for instance in n.7 of Toh 1090/1777; you can refer to the TEI of this text to see how this was done.

With note elements: These may be applied too, however notes cannot have a @key attribute, so they instead need to be included in a seg element; or as mentioned above, differing notes could be used inside different parent elements (p, lg, or l) containing the @key. A single note can also be given child p elements that have separate @keys to make the note display something different in each version. This is commonly done for instance to state the Vol. 88 folio discrepancy for Vol. 88 texts with multiple versions:

note.p: Two sets of folio references have been included in this translation due to a discrepancy in volume 88
In the Toh 527 version of the text there is a slight discrepancy in the folio numbering between

item.p: (see in HTML display here.)

Note that, if the number of notes doesn't match between two texts, this may be an issue from the perspective of a third party citing our texts. It would be ideal to avoid this, especially in a text under a singular title (so they don't end up citing the note of one version that is a different index in another). This issue could be avoided by having parallel notes in respective versions that explain differences from the parallel version. Please be sure that editorial is aware of this issue if the final published text is going to have note numbering that doesn't match.

With milestone elements: If a milestone is skipped it will cause the count to skip in the text it is missing, so this isn't ideal unless it is at the end of a section. Also there is the same issue concerning someone citing the text if the milestone count doesn't match, so be sure that editorial is aware of such a decision.

div.head: Chinese and Other Foreign Scripts
div.p: Chinese scripts need to always be tagged with a @xml:lang="zh" if they are in Chinese script, e.g. "漢語拼音", and be tagged @xml:lang="Zh-Ltn" if they are in pinyin or other Roman transliteration e.g. "Hànyǔ Pīnyīn". They may be tagged with the @xml:lang attribute either with a foreign or title, or a div element in the case of a Chinese Summary (Chinese summaries should be placed immediately after the English summary in its own separate div with an @xml:lang="zh" attribute. It will not be displayed in the English Reading Room but will on the Chinese site). If they are not tagged like this they will not be displayed correctly in a consistent font. The same goes for any Japanese text, which should be tagged "ja" or "Ja-Ltn" in the same manner. There is one exception where we don't need to worry about the tags and that is the Chinese names often found in the sponsor element in the TEI header, these aren't displayed anywhere so they do not need the @xml:lang attribute.

Most of us not knowing Chinese and Japanese will sometimes need to guess according to the context whether the script is "zh" or "ja", however, this is not too important because the parser will display Chinese, Japanese, and Korean in the same CJK-pan. So it's not imperative that they are tagged 100% correctly as long as each instance of CJK unicode is tagged with one of the CJK attributes: either "zh" "ja" or "ko".
The following search codes will allow you to easily locate miss-tagged or missing tags:

list.item: An XPath will locate any Roman letter "a-z" or letter "A-Z" that is mislabelled "zh" or "ja": //text()[matches(., '[a-zA-z]')][ancestor::*[@xml:lang = ('zh') or @xml:lang = ('ja')]]
Using the regular CTRL-F search in Oxygen you can also locate Chinese script with the regex pattern: \p{script=Han}+
And any Japanese script with: [\p{script=Hiragana}\p{script=Katakana}]+
Korean: \p{script=Hangul}+

p.tei:ref: (See more about searching various unicode scripts using regex patterns here)

div.p: Keep an eye out for Chinese in the acknowledgements section and the bibliography where titles and names tend to be missed. Note that when a title is given in both Chinese script and pinyin, then two title tags are needed to separate the language codes: Shirukurōdo to kindai nihon no kaikō: sai’iki kodai shiryō to nihon kindai bukkyō シルクロードと近代日本の邂逅―西域古代資料と日本近代仏教 It's not indispensable to check for these every time since we will occasionally run these searches on the full TEI translation folder, but it might be a good idea to run the scripts on text that especially heavy in Chinese references in the notes and bibliography.

div.head: Cache Files and Re-Caching Publications
div.p:
Although our TEI files contain complete publications, in order to optimize our reader on the web, a cache for each text is kept in a separate file found in 84000-data/cache. The cache contains data regarding the location of end-notes, milestones, Kangyur folio references, and glossary entries (all of these elements are already in the TEI but the cache tells the parser where to find these elements). A published text will need to be re-cached whenever:
A) an endnote, milestone, or Kangyur folio reference has been added or removed.
B) If any glossary entries are linked to new locations (locations are determined by milestone placement).
Glossary entries are cached to improve the web performance. When viewing a text's web display from collaboration in editor mode, you see un-cached glossary instances highlighted in red. These instances will not be linked when the text is pushed to distribution until they are cached

p.hi: A) Re-caching for changes to endnotes, milestones, or folio refs:

div.p: In this first case, the re-cache can simply be done by going to Project Management for the particular text, select "Edit Headers", up the version number and give a note (e.g., "added an endnote") and hit update. It will give you a message "glossary locations may need re-caching" If you made any textual changes you'll need to open the glossary editor and check if any re-caching is needed there, but if you are certain that no textual changes have been made, then this will not be necessary.

Now you can select "Generate new associated files." When you see that the version number of the "CACHE" matches that of the TEI, then you know that the new notes have been cached. The same applies to milestones, and folio references.

p.hi: B) Re-caching for changes to glossary locations:

div.p: In the latter case, the glossary will need to be re-cached from the Glossary Editor. Please refer to Appendix C.4: for details. The glossary may be re-cached before or after clicking "Generate new associated files."

div.head: Commentaries
div.p: The workflow for commentaries is to be further developed as we translate more of them and assess the needs of these publications, but generally they will be entered by copy editors into the "84000 Template for Commentaries," which only differs from the regular template with the inclusion of a few tags for quotes of the root text. Then these quotes will then be manually matched by markup to the milestones of the root text.

div.head: 84000 Template for Commentaries (MS Word)
div.p: The template adds six styles that distinguish "Root text" quotes from "Subsidiary" quotes, and further distinguishes those two as either a "Block-Quote" "Inline-Quote" or "Block-Verse" (i.e. a quote of verse). These all export with a @type attribute that describes them as either "root" or "subsidiary". This @type distinction is arbitrary and not validated by the schema. If the distinction is not needed it can be removed (in the future if this distinction proves to be unproductive we'll remove it from the script). The quotes will all be converted with the appropriate q tags; otherwise, there is no difference from the regular template.

div.head: Linking Commentaries to Root Text
div.p: The documentation for linking commentaries to root texts is found together with the commentary layout checks, which has examples of block quotes which link to the primary layout checks (see examples from the documentation there). To see examples of published commentary linked to its root, see Toh 3808, which links to Toh 8, Toh 9, and Toh 10.
For detailed documentation read the commentary layout checks. But as a brief summary:

list.item: The commentary text needs to have a link element in the sourceDesc declaring it is a commentary, and of which text. E.g.: <link type="isCommentaryOf" target="toh9"/>
The root text does not need such a declaration, but it does need a short code in it's <titleStmt>, which will appear as a link at the end of each block quote (see Toh00c 1.2)

A commentary quote is linked to it's root text by adding the following tag inside the q tag: <ptr type="quote-ref" rend="substring" target="#[MILESTONE IN ROOT TEXT]">. This ptr tag should be inside any p child element. For example:
Thus did I hear
In this example at Toh 3808 1.3, it links to both Toh 9 and Toh 10, and the matching text is highlighted in the pop-up.

However, if the root text differs from the commentary. A orig tag is needed to match what is found in the root text. The <ptr> tag must then go inside the <orig> tag. You may need to add tags from the root text's TEI as well in order to get the highlight to match. For example:
He dwelt at Rājagṛha
on Gṛdhrakūṭa Hill.
on Vulture Peak
Here at Toh 3808, 1.17 the English translation of Toh 10 matches "on Gṛdhrakūṭa Hill" but Toh 9 does not, so the <orig> was added for Toh 9.

There may be a lot of troubleshooting issues to get the highlighting to match. An ellipsis character … can be used to jump the highlight across sections of text, but it should only be used if it is needed or for a very large quote.

item.p: Highlighting some segments may be tricky. The highlighter often has an issue if a segment at the same milestone is quoted twice but has different start and end points. For instance, if one quote is linked to:

q.p: “Furthermore, Lord, bodhisattva great beings practicing the perfection of wisdom should not stand in form,”

item.p: and another qoute late in the commentary is also linked to the same passage but quotes:
The reader won't highlight the first quote properly until the overlap of the two strings is split by an ellipsis "…" break. Therefore the first quote should be changed to:

q.p: “Furthermore, Lord, bodhisattva great beings practicing the perfection of wisdom…should not stand in form,”

item.p: then it should highlight correctly.

list.item: There is an app we developed for checking all the block quotes you can use here (replace the text ID in this URL with that of the commentary). This will help you see which quotes are note highlighting properly.
We are still workshopping a more convenient way to add the highlighting, contact Celso if you have questions.

div.head: Partial Translations in Sections for Large Texts
div.p: The precedent was set with the publication the 100,000 Line Perfection of Wisdom (Toh 8) to publish large texts in partial blocks:

div.head: Some Notes About How the Glossary Works
div.p: Note, also see the Translator Guidelines V.G. Glossary. There is a definitive explanation for translators on how to create their glossaries and these principles should be carried forward in to markup.
div.label: How Reader Handles Plurals:
div.p: A term will be matched if it is followed by s, es, 's, or s' and then a non-word character, e.g. Maitreya, Maitreya's, Maitreyas. (Unfortunately, the general marker for non-word characters is not Sanskrit-aware. It handles Sanskrit diacritic characters as non-word characters. While we have handled most of the related issues in this case it can result in a few mistakes, e.g. Maitreyasāyana).
div.label: Capitalization
div.p: The glossary is not case-sensitive and will link to names and terms regardless of capitalization. However, note that as a standard within the TEI proper names should be capitalized in the English and Sanskrit field but NOT in the Tibetan Wylie field. Although the parser will display all the English and Sanskrit entries in the Reading Room itself as capitalized regardless of the text found in the TEI.
div.label: Use of the term Tag to Mark the Same Word Used in Different Ways:
div.p: Sometimes we will only want certain instances of a string of text to be marked as a glossary term. For example, perhaps we want the term "appropriate" to be linked to this term when it is used as verb but not when it used as an adjective. The translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the “†” symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate" (These should not be left in the text but replaced with the markup described in the following section). However, many of these may be missed and so all the linked terms should be checked in markup. Note, that we are no longer using zero-width-non-joiners to resolve this issue. Instead, we now use the "mode" attribute within the gloss element.

In the glossary, gloss nodes can be given the attributes mode="match|marked." Match mode will highlight any matches in the text except where they have been marked up with term rend="ignore", e.g.: parse this but not this
*Note that a term in the definition field of a glossary entry linking to itself is ignored automatically.
Marked mode will only match terms that have been marked up with term e.g. Ignore this but match this.
div.label: How Tibetan Is Created from Wylie:
div.p: Where a glossary item has a Wylie term but no Tibetan the database will auto-generate the Tibetan. To re-create a Tibetan term simply remove the node, save, and refresh. The Wylie string will also have a trailing space enforced. These will produce the respective syllable separators in the Tibetan. Double underscores in Wylie will be replaced with a single space when output to the reader.

If later you make a correction to a Tibetan entry, be sure to delete the term with Tibetan Unicode (the one with xml:lang="bo") this will trigger the database to auto-generate a new one from the corrected Wylie entry, but if you leave it as is the error will remain in the Tibetan Unicode.
div.label: Links to Paragraphs with Instances:
div.p: The reader lists links to each paragraph that includes instances of a glossary term.
div.label: For Multiple Tibetan and Sanskrit Forms of Spelling for a Single Term:
div.p: In some cases a single gloss entry may have multiple forms for spelling the Tibetan, the Sanskrit, or both. In this case each spelling of the term can be listed separately in its own term element. However, Tibetan should be listed first, followed by the Sanskrit, as in the following example for the term "karnikara" (note that a Tibetan "bo" term is auto-generated after each instance of Tibetan Wylie "Bo-Ltn"):

gloss.term: Pterospermum acerifolium. Other names include bayur, muchakunda, muchalinda, and dinner-plate tree.

p.tei:ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

div.p: Note that in the example above, these spelling variations are supplied by the author but don't actually appear in the translated text. If there are alternative spellings of a term within the text itself, they need to be marked as type="translationAlternative."
div.label: Use of Alternatives in the Glossary Entry:
div.p: Glossary items can also include term type="translationAlternative" nodes to specify other variations in the spelling that should be marked in the text:

p.tei:ref: (See in the Reading Room; note that the alternative term isn't listed in the glossary but is linked in the text as the third occurrence).

div.p:
Alternatives may be added for any related terms that should be linked to the entry such as:
When a plural "-s" appears in the middle of the string in certain cases and is not linking (as in the XML example above), or not linking because the plural has an irregular spelling, e.g. "phenomena" and "phenomenon"; "birth-story" and "birth-stories"; etc...
Alternate nominal or verbal uses of the same term: appropriate, appropriated, appropriation.
Extended names such as "Mañjuśrī" and "Mañjuśrī the crown prince". In this last case only if the simple name is clearly represented in the extended one, otherwise a second gloss should be added referring to the primary one, e.g.: The Great Compassionate One -- See Avalokiteśvara.

However, alternatives should not be used for two semantically different English words, even if they are translated from the same Tibetan term and have similar meaning. For example if "offering" and "worship" are both used for "mchod pa / pūjā". They should be given two different glossary entries.
The 84000 translator's guidelines (G4) states this clearly:

If the same Tibetan or Sanskrit word was translated in more than one way, include an entry for each, and place in the definition a reference to the other rendering, e.g. for the entry “Offering” (mchod pa / pūjā): “Also translated here as ‘worship,’ ” (and vice versa for the entry “Worship”).

There are two reasons for this. (1) We don't want readers unfamiliar with Tibetan and Sanskrit clicking on a term like "worship" and having it link to "offering," and (2) Some readers may be reading the text in a PDF format or even someday in print and will need to look up terms alphabetically as the hyperlinks won't be available.

Some of these alternatives may have been entered improperly and will need to be separated into separate entries. This should be handled by copy editors, but in some cases it may be missed and markup editors will be more capable of spotting inconsistencies or issues in the glossary since they will be able to actually click on the links and check them in the Reading Room.

There has been some further discussion regarding whether alternatives should be used when the English words for a glossary entry are used in a different word order. So in the example above for "door of the dharma" one might ask, should this itself be used as an alternative linking to the entry for "dharma-door" or should it be in a separate entry? In this case it isn't such an issue that the reader would click on "door of the Dharma" and see the entry for "Dharma-door" but it is an issue for anyone reading the PDF. However it is quite sensible that the reader would simply search for the term under "dharma" if they did not find it in "door". If there are a just a few instances of these it makes sense to create separate entries, but if the amount of entries with alternate word order is becoming extensive then this could be an issue because it will muddy up the glossary, be difficult for reader to find all the instances of a term from the "passages contain this term" field, and also it could muddy up the cumulative glossary. When there are a lot of such alternatives it may be better to set such phrases as "door of the dharma" as an alternative provided that it would be sensible from the perspective of the reader and there aren't semantically distinct words (e.g., you wouldn't want to add "gateway of the dharma" as an alternative). If there are a lot of such instances, you should also check with the editors about changing the translation to be more consistent (make notes about such instances in the Reading Room Worksheet). This should be taken on a case by case basis and always thought of from the readers perspective.
div.label: Further Explanation on the Mode Attribute:
div.p: The mode attribute is not required, but when present it can either be "match" or "marked." "Match" is the default (where this attribute is not specified). "Match" will behave in the normal way: the text is scanned for glossary matches and highlighted accordingly.
"Marked," on the other hand, will only consider text strings that have been marked up with term. An example for "appropriate" is below:

egXML.p: Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, appropriate another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it appropriate different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?”

p.tei:ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

div.label: Linking terms in the body of the text to the glossary entry directly with the @ref attribute.
div.p: Sometimes, if there are three or more glossary entries with the same exact string, the marked application alone will not be sufficient. In this case the duplicate gloss entries should all be tagged mode="marked" and the terms within the body of the text may be linked directly to the proper glossary entry by adding a @ref attribute that points that term to the specific entry attributed to it. For example there are three separate entries for the name "Upananda" in Toh 340. These may be distinguished in the text as follows:

egXML.p: He had come to Śrāvastī very late, and seeing that the other monks had already gone carrying their alms bowls filled, he thought, “I will ask where I should go to quickly get some alms.” So he went to see Upananda and asked him,
King Prasenajit implored the Blessed One, “Lord, the Blessed One has tamed vicious nāgas like Nanda, Upananda,

div.label: Blocking the glossary from linking to entire paragraphs, stanzas, divisions, or mantras
div.p: Optionally an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute may be added to any p, lg, div, or mantra element to block all the text within from linking to the glossary. Typically we want to do this for Sanskrit appendices, long Sanskrit quotes, or mantras where the complex Sanskrit spelling declinations will cause terms to be linked inconsistently. Note, the @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute can ostensibly be used on any element in the TEI document although the schema may need to be updated to validate it in particular cases. Email the ODD editor (Celso) if the schema needs to be updated.
div.label: Some Final Tips for Polishing the Glossary:

list.item: Sometimes a term will appear in its own definition. By default the parser will block these from linking to themselves.
If there are references in the definition to a term, such as "see also...", they can be placed into a second term type="definition" line, to create some visual lightness in the final webdisplay.

If a word is not linking in the webdisplay, here are some common causes for instances not being detected by the parser:
Plurals in the middle of strings of words (where the "s" doesn't come at the end).
An extra space at the end of the term in the glossary.
Sanskrit soft-hypens in the term not matching with the glossary entry.

Occasionally you will see a word in the text that is similar to a glossary term but isn't linked because it takes as different form. For instance, "appropriate" is in the glossary, but you see "appropriation" in the text. If you see instances like this you can add an term type="translationAlternative" to that gloss item, but be sure that you are not then linking to other unwanted instances as well.

div.head: Applying Type Attributes for the Sanskrit Term
div.p: Translators are instructed to add codes for the attestation for Sanskrit terms (and possibly Tibeta/Chinese ones) in the glossary:

item.p: This term is attested in the Sanskrit manuscript used as a source for this translation. [Adds "AS" marker]
This term is attested in other Sanskrit manuscripts of the Kangyur or Tengyur. [Adds "AO" marker]
This term is attested in Tibetan-Sanskrit dictionaries. [Adds "AD" marker]
The attestation of this name is approximate. It is based on other names where Tibetan-Sanskrit relationship is attested in dictionaries or other manuscripts. [Adds "AA" marker]

This term is a reconstruction based on the Tibetan phonetic rendering of the term--that is to say Tibetan transliteration of the Sanskrit found in the Tibetan source. [Adds an asterisk to beginning of term and "RP" marker]
This term is a reconstruction based on the semantics of the Tibetan translation. [Adds an asterisk to beginning of term and "RS" marker]
This term has been supplied from an unspecified source, which most often is a widely trusted dictionary. [This is the default, does not add an asterisk; does not add "SU" marker]

div.p: These types should be generated automatically in the latest version of the TEI conversion script. If an incorrect code was entered then it will display that code in an invalid <bad-no-attestation-type> tag. If the attestation was left blank then the empty tags should be removed with a search/replace. The attestation doesn't necessarily need to be documented for every glossary, but if possible, check with the editor in charge of the text and if there is no documentation of the Skt. sources used apply “sourceUnspecified”.
In case there is any ambiguity for which attestation type to apply, we've created a google document to post and resolve ambiguities here.

div.head: Caching and Re-caching the Glossary
div.p: Note that the glossary needs to be specifically re-cached from the Glossary Editor, while when endnotes, milestones, or folio references should be re-cached from project management (see Appendix B TOPICS: ).
To re-cached from the Glossary Editor: Click on "Batch update options" and selecting "Re-cache location of all entries". This will re-cache the glossary according to the current matching and modes.

Some large texts, particularly ones with extensive glossaries may take a long time to re-cache (the longest example of this is Toh 94 which currently takes about 6 hours), however most of texts should only take a few seconds. Note that the time it took previously to re-cache will be displayed by the editor.

This re-cache function runs in the background, so you can work on other things or open other texts in the editor while it is running. It will continue to display the message "job running, please wait" until the re-cache is complete. (to check if it is done, run a new search, refreshing the page doesn't always work in this case).

After re-caching the glossary editor will tell you:
How many entries are cached behind the current version. It will display this in the header e.g. "63 Behind". This is the number of entries that were cached in the previous cache file. This can be searched as "Cached behind".
How many entries have newly cached locations. This will display in the header e.g. "3 new". This is the number of entries with newly cached locations. This should be double checked to make sure they were intended to be cached. If they look fine, then no further actions are needed, however if there are some that shouldn't be cached, please correct them in the TEI and re-cache again.
Any missing entries will be flagged as "missing". These locations have been lost for some reason and should be investigated/corrected in the TEI.

If it is a large text and it will take an long time to re-cache, it is suitable to just cache glossary entries individually if you're certain that only a few glossary entries have changed. For example if you needed to add one glossary entry, "nāga" to Toh 94, instead of doing a full recache, you could instead add the entry, then search in the glossary editor for the entry "nāga" and click "cache locations". Then you would update the file version say from v1.0.1 to v1.0.2, but leave the cache as v1.0.1, then when you push the TEI for v1.0.2 it will properly link to the locations of the instance "nāga" because those locations have been added to v1.0.1 when you clicked "cache locations" of "nāga". Thus you have avoided the 6 hours wait and CPU usage to cache just one entry.

div.head: Transform the Glossary from the Spreadsheet
div.p: Typically, the glossaries are converted from tables in the 84000 .docx template, but if the glossary was instead entered into an .xslx spreadsheet, please follow the instructions as follows:

list.item: Before transforming the glossary with the script, make sure that the tables are formatted properly. In Excel, there should be three or four sheets labeled "Terms", "People", "Places", and on occasion there will be a fourth sheet that should be labeled "Texts". If the labels of the sheets aren't spelled exactly like this, then the script won't apply the correct type to the gloss elements. Each sheet/table needs to have seven columns that are to be exactly arranged as follows: (A) Tibetan Wylie, (B) Sanskrit, (C) Skt Source, (D) Chinese (optional), (E) Translation, (F) Definition, and (G) Alternatives. (See also the template in the shared google drive). Older templates will only have five columns and so the missing ones can be filled by right clicking and inserting blank ones from MS Word.

item.label: Using a Macro to Correct Initial Apostrophes:

list.item: When you receive a glossary file in an Excel spreadsheet format, it’s likely there will be hidden apostrophes in the wylie column. This happens when a straight apostrophe is typed at the beginning of the word, as in the case of an a-chung prefix, "འ". Excel uses straight apostrophes to override the cell's format when typing numbers so that it considers it as text. In the process it hides this initial apostrophe, although there actually is an apostrophe in the cell, i.e., it disappears unless one actually clicks on the cell and looks in the text box at the top of the screen. In some cases the translator may have entered two apostrophes by mistake, or put one where there shouldn't be one. In all cases, these will need to be corrected, as the translator should not use straight apostrophes in the wylie text at all, but only use left curving apostrophes (’) (otherwise the script will not display proper Tibetan Unicode below them). Interestingly, the invisible apostrophes are not carried over if you copy a table and paste it into the Glossary Template, However, these initial apostrophes still need to be checked because the author may have thought they had correctly placed one into the beginning of a cell, but then the apostrophe will have disappeared and won't get carried over to the Template. To make this check and fix any errors, you should run the following macro in Excel. This macro will convert each initial straight apostrophe. However, most often these are a spelling error in the wylie transliteration and will need to be corrected (each instance must be verified in a Tibetan dictionary). To make these instances easy to find, the macro also adds “111” so that it’s easy to make a search for these cells. The “111” is just a marker and will obviously need to be removed too.

In case you don't know how to run a macro in Excel, there are many tutorials available on Youtube for both PC and Mac. There might be some differences depending on the version of your Excel software, but they should be pretty straightforward. You may be prevented from running a macro if the file is "shared"; you may have to go to the "Review" tab, click on "Share Workbook," and uncheck the box to share the file with other users (this might be slightly different on Mac). Then you should be able to run the macro without any problem. Here is the macro. Paste the following code into a module window and hit "run":
Sub AposChange()
Dim Rng As Range, Cell As Range
ThisWorkBook.Activate
Set Rng = Cells.SpecialCells(xlConstants)
Cells(Rows.Count, Columns.Count).Copy
For Each Cell In Rng
If Cell.PrefixCharacter = "'" Then
Cell.Value = "111 ’" + Cell.Value
Cell.PasteSpecial Operation:=xlPasteSpecialOperationAdd
End If
Next Cell
Application.CutCopyMode = False
End Sub

Here is an example. When you look at the spreadsheet you will see: ’khor ba ’jig But in the file there is actually a hidden apostrophe: '’khor ba ’jigSo after running the macro script it will become: 111 ’’khor ba ’jig In this example there should be no hesitation about what to remove, but in other cases you may need to check in the dictionary.

Note this macro only runs on one sheet at a time, and it only works on the first sheet in a .xlsx document, so you will need to copy the second and third sheet into new spreadsheet files, open each sheet separately in Excel, and then run the macro separately for each. (Sorry this is such a long process, this is probably a good reason for us to do all the glossaries from an MS Word template in the future.)

list.item: This transformation may be done through the submissions form in the project management app, just the same way you converted the main text, (see instructions again at A.2). Alternatively you may convert the file through oxgarage, (currently this is needed if the .docx from the glossary template is used, although the submissions form will be updated to import this soon). div.head: Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document
div.p: Milestones are applied to the document with the “milestone unit="chunk"/” tag. Because the 84000 reading room does not have page numbers, milestones are particularly important for referencing sections or paragraphs in the text.

Generally milestones should be placed at the beginning of every paragraph and at the beginning of every stanza of verse. However, in cases where paragraphs are exceptionally short--ones that only extend one or two lines across the reader on a typical computer screen--then one milestone may be used for two short paragraphs. Note that by default, the TEI script will generate a milestone for every paragraph or stanza of verse and superflous milestones should be removed by the markup editor.

It should be noted that earlier publications (up until mid-2023) had guidelines which placed milestones more sparsely apart. However, it was determined that it is better to have more milestones than less because it gives the ability to cite passages more precisely. Therefore, we have updated the guidelines to only require trimming milestones in the case of exceptionally short paragraphs as defined above.

Here is an example of using a single milestone for two very short paragraphs of dialogue. Note, that if this is done, it is best to keep a question and it's answer within the same milestone if possible:

egXML.p: “Blessed Lord, is enlightenment then attained by a path that arises?”
“No!” replied the Blessed One.

lg.l: Pure are your eyes, broad and beautiful, like the petals of a blue lotus.
Pure is your thought, having discovered the supreme transcendence of all trances.
Immeasurable is the ocean of your virtues, the accumulation of your good deeds.
You affirm the path of peace. O Great Ascetic, obeisance to you!
Leader, bull of men, we behold the revelation of your miracle.
The superb and radiant fields of the sugatas appear before us,
And your extensive spiritual teachings, that lead to immortality
Make themselves heard throughout the whole reach of space.
Dharma-King, you rule with the Dharma your supreme Dharma-kingdom,
And thereby bestow the treasures of the Dharma upon all living beings.
Expert in the deep analysis of things, you teach their ultimate meaning.
Sovereign Lord of Dharma, obeisance to you!

div.head: Guidelines for Entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit
div.p: Note that only editors with a basic understanding of the spelling and sandhi rules of Sanskrit should proceed with this step. You don't need to be an expert in Sanskrit, as most words can be looked up in online references, however, for this step editors will need to have a clear grasp on how the sandhi rules in Sanskrit work. If not please request that another editor with this skill to complete this task.

list.item: Look for long Sanskrit chains, and add optional soft-hyphens at points where there are chains that are 15+ characters long. Optional soft-hyphens are created with the character code: ­ Or keep a copy of the character in a text file for copy/pasting, sorry I can't paste it here because it will disappear in the HTML, but note that after you save the XML and refresh these will look like regular hyphens, but if you move the blinking cursor to the space just before the hyphen you will notice there is a different character code, "U+00AD" displayed at the bottom of the oXygen screen. You can then copy and paste the character into a text file for later use.

The long Sanskrit chains can be found easily by going to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder, then in the XPath/XQuery Builder window type the following code and press the red play button://*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn'] You can save this query for later by clicking on the star and choosing "add to favourites."

Note that texts that have Sanskrit appendixes will not be checked by the code above because these sections aren't marked with an @xml:lang attribute. Generally, the Sanskrit appendixes such as the one in Toh 437 does not need soft hyphens because it is not anticipated that they will be read on small devices. However, occasionally there may be extremely long strings in the appendices that will fill the screen even on a regular web browser. For the appendices our current limit is any strings longer than 40 continuous characters without as space. To search the appendices, press CTRL/SHIFT/H to "search in files" then check the "regular expression" box, in the scope select "All open files", and in "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code: //text(). Finally, in the search field enter the following regex code: (^|\s|-­)[^\s-­]{40,}($|\s|-­). This should give you a list of all the 40+ strings while ignoring tags, spaces, or hyphens.

Be careful when adding the soft hyphens as they should only be placed at certain points in the words where they do not interfere with the Sanskrit rules of sandhi. When adding the soft hyphens please follow the following guidelines:

item.label: Guidelines for Adding Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit:

item.p: 1. As we are not using full justification anyway, (a) most Sanskrit words don’t need hyphenation unless they are longer than 5 or 6 syllables, but (b) may be necessary for shorter words especially in text titles on the title page. I therefore tend to place soft hyphens in all of the text titles, in verse passages, in the bibliography entries, and in notes and glossary entries (which require shorter lines in general).

2. Place a soft hyphen (a) only between the words of a compound; (b) even then only when there are no changes brought about by sandhi (because putting a hyphen would logically mean undoing the sandhi, and the hyphens we’re talking about may or may not appear); and (c) avoiding confusing remnants.
A couple of examples:

Ratnagotravibhāgottaratantraśāstra would be Ratna-gotra-vibhāgottara-tantra-śāstra. If we divided the 5-syllable sequence in the middle, that would have to undo the sandhi and become -vibhāga-uttara-, which only works in the presence of a hard hyphen. Theoretically we could put a hyphen at vi-bhāga, but that would risk leaving us with -gotravi-, which would be potentially confusing to read.

The maximum we could hyphenate antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhisaṃdhisamuccedaka would be antānanta-ḍṛṣṭi-vāsanābhi-saṃdhi-sam-ucchedaka, because antānanta and vāsanābhi-saṃdhi would become anta-ananta and vāsana-abhi-saṃdhi. In a case like that, I would also prefer to avoid ending up with antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhi-saṃdhisamuccedaka, because the abhi- really belongs with the saṃdhi; it’s a possible break but is confusing to read.

One resource that is helpful for determining the breaks in Sanskrit chains in the online Cologne Sanskrit Dictionary. This one is really helpful because it has a drop down menu of similarly spelled words when you hit the enter key. Then when you find a big word in the dictionary in the definition entry you will see * whenever there is sandhi, though this isn't 100% reliable. Sometimes it is missing for some reason, so be careful if the spelling looks weird.

***Important Note*** Soft-hyphens are also needed for the "mainTranslation" field and matching strings the consist of long Sanskrit compounds. There are some "Persons" and "Places" that occasionally use the untranslated Sanskrit for the main translation, these will not be flagged by the XPath code because, as proper nouns, they aren't typically italicized and therefore aren't tagged with @xml:lang="Sa-Ltn". However, it is easy to identify these because they will match the Sanskrit field in the glossary entry which will be flagged by the XPath. For this reason I typically check the Sanskrit by going backwards through the TEI, and when the Sanskrit field in the glossary entries is flagged I look at the “mainTranslation” field to see if it replicates the Sanskrit. If so, then soft hyphens should be applied in the same manner to the "mainTranslation" field, and then a search and replace is needed throughout the text because these soft hyphens affect how strings are linked to the glossary. However, be mindful of the capitalization, as the term may be contained as a sub-segment in a longer string, so it's better to do a step-through search and replace rather than replacing all at once. Changing these Sanskrit strings in the glossary are important because otherwise the "our translation" field will be cut off for long strings in the app or if read on the screen of a phone.

In certain cases there may be long 15+ Sanskrit chains that cannot be broken due to the sandhi, or long Sanskrit compounds whose pieces cannot be easily determined with online resources. If this is the case make a list of problematic instances to note for the leading editors, and also check these instances to see if the pose any major difficultly for the web display. These instances are rare, but they do come up now and then.
It is acceptable to add an optional hyphen at the end of "mahā-" as in "mahā-yāna" even though technically the long ā would be lost, as this is a well known word and unlikely to be misread.

div.head: Text Mysteriously Appearing in TEI from Hidden Text in the MS Word Document
div.p: Occasionally you may see a string of gibberish mysteriously appears in the middle of the TEI file. This issue occurs when a string is applied as "hidden" through the Font menu in MS Word (Right-Click -> Font -> then check "Hidden"). The problem is that our TEI conversion scripts makes the string of text reappear when it is converted from DOCX to TEI. This reappearance is implemented in the initial OxGarage script, so I am unable to remedy it with our own XSLT script.

A segment of “Hidden”text could be inadvertently contained inside a DOCX submitted for publication, it's very rare since it seems like one would need to do it intentionally, but it could possibly occur when a .DOCX file is edited from an alternate word processor in the translation process (this is just my theory). Since it is hidden in the document it goes unnoticed in our own copyediting phase, but reappears in the TEI.

However, there is an easy way to check if a text has “Hidden” text:
(1) On Windows, right click the DOCX file -> “rename” the file, and change the file type from “.docx” to “.zip”. It will give you a warning, but just hit okay.
(2) Then extract that “.zip” file with an archive extractor like WinZip, 7Zip, or whatever.
(3) Then use a texteditor like Notepad++ or Oxygen that has a “Searchfolder” application and search the extracted archive for the tag: w:vanish Any instance of the tag will show you "hidden" text which will appear in the TEI after the conversion; you should then evaluate whether those specific strings were intended to be in the text but were accidentally removed, or if they are remnant edits that shouldn't be there. An example can be found as follows: go to Project Management and download the last .docx for Toh 257 "toh-257-quintessence-of-the-sun-for-markup-apr-18-2022.docx", performing the search method above will reveal a "<w:vanish>But h<w:vanish/>" tag). In this instance it was a remnant edit that seemed to be preserved from an earlier time (this led me to believe that some of these are saves from alternate word processors).

This situation is pretty rare, so it's probably not necessary to check every time. But, do check if (A) you notice odd strings showing up in the middle of your markup, or (B) this check should be performed for any large complex text, especially if it was passed around a lot between different parties.

div.head: Guide and Checklist for Updating the Schema and ODD
div.p: Note that updating the schema and ODD is a bit more complicated, so this should be handled by the lead editors or technicians. Otherwise, if you are working on a markup and notice that the schema needs to be updated (i.e., there is some markup needed but you are getting a schema error for that markup), then make this a point to send to the lead editors in your final list of questions and issues for finalizing the text. Please disregard the following instructions unless you are a lead editor or technician.

list.item: This appendix gives a brief explanation and checklist for how to update the ODD. However, you may need to refer to the 22nd chapter of the TEI guidelines for a more detailed explanation on how the elements in the ODD work. You may also need to refer to the 23rd chapter of the TEI guidelines which contains information on the content models, attribute customizations, and TEI conformance.

Most of the restrictions in the ODD are defined in the element specifications. In order to create documentation, an elementSpec has been created for all of the elements we use. There are also some schema restrictions defined in class specifications, classSpec, and macro specifications, macroSpec. In our ODD's XML the classSpecs are listed first followed by the macroSpecs followed by the elementSpecs all in alphabetical order. If you need to jump to a specific element, they can easily be found by searching for their ident attribute. For example, to find the elementSpec for the "front", search for c ident="front" and this will take you to that section of the ODD.

Adding new elements will require creating a new elementSpec and adding it to the ODD. Adding or modifying attributes can be done in that specific element's attList. For example here is the attList for the title element:
classifies the title according to the TBRC typology. classifies the title according to the 84000 typology.
The attDef defines a particular attribute for title, along with a description desc. The valList defines what values are allowed in the "type" attribute. Since we don't use the default "xml:id" and "level" attributes in our titles they have been set to "delete" so they won't appear in our documentation. We want the "xml:lang" to be required for all titles so the usage has been set to "reg". More details should can be found in the TEI guidelines.

When a language needs to be added to the schema, the language list is actually found in the class specification for "att.global" that defines the "xml:lang" attribute. It should be added here so it will apply to all the elements that use "xml:lang". To find this section search for attDef ident="xml:lang"

Content Models: The structure for the schema--i.e., what elements are allowed to be nested in what elements--are contained in the ODD content models, content. Each element used in our TEI has a content model defined in its element specification, or if it isn't stated then the default TEI content model will be used when the schema is generated in from Oxgarage. You can look up the default content model in the appendix of the TEI Guidelines Because the 84000 schema is very restrictive, we use often directly use relax ng code within the ODD to define content models for the structure of the text. That is why you will see the prefix "rng:-" before many of the elements there. When the content model needs to be updated, that is the rules which govern how the elements are to be nested, look for the content element in the ODD for that element's elementSpec. If is a global rule for that element it will be found there. However, keep in mind if it is a rule specific to the order or structure found in the front, body, or back, then the content model will be found in those element's content models.

To avoid writing repetitive code, there are also some content models declared in the marcroSpec these may be referred to in other content models, which will look something like this:
In this example the rng element points to the content model of our basic paragraph. And if that needs to be updated in can be done so in the macroSpec for "paragraph".

Note there are also many descriptions, desc, as well as examples egXML contained in all the specifications. It is not required to update these for the generation of the schema, but when you make in update, it would be good to update these as well so that our documentation can be most up to date. Also consider whether an update is something that the markup editors need to be aware of during their work flow. If it is, please add some explanation and/or protocol for the markup editors in the "Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors". This appendix is found in the back of the ODD.

Occasionally, we may add a new element to our schema that is already included in one of the standard TEI modules. Note, that these standard elements are all declared at the beginning of the ODD in the moduleRef. This happened to me, I couldn't figure out why the hi element wasn't validating even though it was declared in an elementSpec. The reason was I had assumed it was declared as a part of the "core" module, but had forgotten to add it to the list within the moduleRef.

If you can't figure out why an added element or attribute isn't validating properly for a schema update. A good technique is to paste that element into a TEI document apply the schema, and read the schema error message at the bottom of the oXygen window. It should tell you what the schema is expecting and based on that you can determine where and which content model needs to be updated. Also keep in mind that any element from the standard TEI modules will have the default content model if a new one isn't declared, so you may need to look up the element in the TEI guidelines to find its default content model as well as its other parameters.

To summarize here is a brief checklist for any updates for the ODD/schema.
1) Make any changes to the element that needs update in that elements elementSpec
2) Does this change need to be reflected in the content model? If so make the appropriate corrections to the content found within the elementSpecs for the teiHeader, front, body, back, or possibly one of the macroSpecs
3) Update examples, egXML and/or descriptions desc if needed.
4) Update the markup editor's checklist if needed.

div.head: XPath/XQuery and Other oXygen Search Tools

label.hi: Further Useful Tips for using the XPath/XQuery Builder

list.item: The Xpath/XQuery builder is a useful tool for searching for unwanted stuff in the glossaries like brackets, slashes and so on. To open, go to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder

For example to search for a bracket withing the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(")] The "(" at the end is what determines the bracket. Enter this into the XPath/XQuery Builder and press the play button to perform the search.
To find an opening square bracket in the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(") or contains(text(), "[")]

By using backslashes and element names you can also look for specific terms within particular elements, for example to search for a certain "word" within the note elements, you could use this code: //note[contains(data(), 'word')] Here 'word' is what you are looking for. // means search everywhere, //note means search everywhere for notes.
You can save your search codes for later by clicking on the star icon.
To learn more about XPath syntax and how it works. There is a good tutorial here.
Also this section of the tutorial here, explains some syntax, which you should be able to use with the XPath/XQuery Builder.
Find footnote by index (e.g. 12): //note[@xml:id eq //*:end-note[@index eq '12']/@id]
Find glossary by index (e.g. 12): //gloss[@xml:id eq //*:gloss[@index eq '12']/@id]
Find Sanskrit string length 15 or more: //*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn']

You may notice that when you search for certain phrases in the XML, the phrase may not be found in the "Find/Replace" dialog. This is because the search tool is very precise so it will not find phrases with two or more words that are separated by a line break unless you specify it to do so. One way around this is to use the "Find in files" (click the second smaller magnifying glass in the ribbon or CTRL/SHIFT/H). Then select "All opened files" (It will ask you to save before it searches) and make sure "Ignore white spaces" is checked ("Regular expressions" must be unchecked for it to work). It will then ignore the line breaks.

The method above doesn't work with regular expressions. If you need to search in this way with regular expressions, then try replacing the spaces in your code with: \s+, e.g. search "door of dharma" with "door\s+of\s+dharma"
On occasion you may want to search the XML while ignoring all the tags. To do this, again use "find in files" CTRL/Shift/H and in the field that says "Restrict to XPath;" enter the code //text()

This will ignore the tags in your search results. Note, it will ignore the tags but it can't search over tags if a tag appears in the middle of a searched phrase, so for instance it won't fine "vidyā being" in the XML for vidyā being

div.head: Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document
div.p: The three digit version numbering (e.g., "v 1.2.1") we are using here refer respectively to "major", "minor", and "revision" changes to the text (This emulates software versioning standards).

Any changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual updates that don't substantially affect the text (typos, minor markup/formatting consistencies, etc.). A change from 1.2.1 to 1.2.2 signals to the reader that there is no need to download it. Any change in the second decimal relates to a minor, but more significant changes within the text itself as well as to significant markup changes. For example, a missing stanza has been added, or a misspelled term has been corrected throughout the text. A change from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0 indicates that readers should download the latest version to have an improved version of the text. Any change in the first decimal would be a major change to the text, so 1.3.1 to 2.0.0. would be a clear sign that it should be downloaded.
To summarize:

list.item: Changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.3.5
Changes in the second decimal relate to minor, but more significant textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.4.0
Changes in first decimal relate to major text changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 2.0.0

div.p: Most texts that have not been started in the translation process have no version number. When a text receives its first update it will change to
When markup is started, the text gets an initial version number:

From that point on, version numbers will increase every time editors feel it’s necessary as they work on the text. As noted before, changes made to the second decimal point are reserved for more significant textual and markup edits, and changes made to the third decimal point are reserved for minor textual and markup edits. Theoretically, a text could go through many versions before it is ready for publication, eg
When the text is ready for publication then the version number is set by the markup editor to

label.hi: When updating the TEI to a published translation please use the following procedure:

list.item: (1) Save your changes from Oxygen.

(2) If you changed any of the markup, run the automated tests on the individual file by clicking on "run tests" next to the text title from the Utilities page (Note: don't run the automated tests from the "tests" tab unless it is necessary to check all the texts, as this will uses up a lot of the server's resources). Correct any issues related to failing test results or inform tech (Dom) about any test updates that may be needed.

(3) Finally, after saving the TEI from Oxygen, the version number needs to be updated separately on the project management page. This is important to keep track of any changes we've made to the published text: From the project management page, find the text according to its "text status," then click on "edit headers." From here, update both the version number (as described in the guidelines above) and if necessary the version's date (entering for the date only a four digit year, e.g., "2019"). Note, the "Publication Date" refers to the date of the original publication, so please leave this unchanged. Please also add a brief note in the "Add a note about this version" field about what changes were made. Now, click the "Update" button. Updating the version number in this way will simultaneously update the editionStmt's version and date within the TEI file, upload the latest version to the Github repository, and generate the newest version of the eBook and PDF (this last part of the update only occurs if it is status="1").
(4) Note that unless the change is urgent, you do not need to push the file to distribution. This will be handled in a weekly check by the revision lead (Martina).

div.p: Note that there is a delay when pushing to distribution. It sometimes takes 6-8 hours to see changes updated. If you want to assure that the changes will be made change the URL on distribution from "...read" to "...direct-read" e.g.: change "https://read.84000.co/translation/toh83.html" to "https://direct-read.84000.co/translation/toh83.html". This will show you the pending updates.

Occasionally, global changes will need to be made for all the texts, usually performed with a script or a search-and-replace in the translations folder (By the way if you make global search-and-replaces to a folder be sure that Oxygen's "Make back of files with extension" box is unchecked, as this will cause problems in the database). Since it would be time consuming to update each text manually, please follow this protocol for updating the texts manually:
1.) Make the global change (using script or find and replace). Make sure that the operation has worked correctly.
2.) Ask tech (Dominic) to run a script to update version numbers and add a descriptive note.
3.) Take a snapshot to capture version history for git (This is on the Utilities page menu: "Make a Data Snapshot").
4.) Assess whether pdfs, epubs, and html need to be republished immediately. If so, then do it manually using utilities. If not, then wait for the next change that warrants a republishing of the text. Especially minor changes may not warrant updating all the publications as texts will be updated periodically, and the change will be added eventually.

Whenever you make changes to a published text, you should always change the version number from project management. When you start working on a text in markup use a version number beginning with 0.1.1. Generally, we don't need a versioning history while the text is in the markup process, however, if the markup for a text is particularly complex, e.g., it is a very large text, it includes attributes that require us to come up with new markup language, it includes a complex outline structure, etc., you should occasionally update the version (e.g., 0.1.2) from project management as you processes different stages of the markup. In such cases, it would also be a good idea to occasionally save a backup locally to your computer. This way we can track the text, and especially have a way of knowing what version it is in case something goes wrong (which does happen from time to time).

div.head: Guidelines for Checking Older Versions of the TEI Documents in the Github Repository:
div.p: Sometimes there may have been an edition or correction that was made in an earlier version of a TEI file that was made in error or for some other reason we need to check that changes that were made in an earlier version of a document. In such cases, all the older versions of the XML are saved as snapshots in 84000's Github repository. To check older versions of the TEI please follow these steps below:

head.hi: Read or Download Archived Files on Github

list.item: Go to the translations folder on 84000's Github repository using this link. You do not need a Github account to check the version history.
From there you will be able to navigate to the TEI file you need. The repository should have the same outline and structure as the TEI database we work from on Oxygen.
Once you navigated to the file you need click on the "History" button. This will take you to a new screen showing you a history of all the snapshots of the file, called "commits" on Github.

By clicking on each commit, it will show you all the additions and deletions that were made to the file at that time. The version number update should be close to the top of the page. From here, it is very convenient to see what changes have been made to the file for each version update.

Or you can simply download that version of the TEI file by first clicking on the three dots ... to the right of the file name of that version, click "view file", the new screen click on the "download" button. (Note that some browsers will just open the XML on a new page, so you might need to right-click "Save Link As..." to download the actual file.

div.p: All the older versions of the files should be here since the time we begin syncing this Github repository. Note that sometimes there may have been a few version updates before a commit, but there should be a record of all the differences between the version at the time of the commit and the previous one.

head.hi: View Archived TEI in the Reading Room Display

list.item: If needed, it is also possible to see how older versions of the TEI display in the Reading Room. First download the desired version of the TEI from Github following the instructions above.

From the database explorer go to the folder in Collaboration/db/apps/84000-data/archived/tei/reference, then right click on the folder and select "import files." Select the file from your computer that you downloaded from Github.

The following URL, with the Toh number entered into the TohXXX will load the archived file to the Reading Room on Collaboration: https://read.84000-translate.org/translation/tohXXX.html?archive-path=tei/reference
The suffix "?archive-path=tei/reference" will likely work with some of the other formats as well.
Note, there is currently an issue with this method; it doesn't work for Toh numbers's with a dash, e.g., "1-1"

div.p: There may also be some versions of antiquated formats in the repository, so if you don't see what you are looking for in the translations folder, you can also search in the main branch.

div.head: Reporting Typos or Errors in the eKangyur:
div.p: The eKangyur is typically very precise, but occasionally there may have been an error when they were inputting the text. If you suspect a typo in the eKangyur, please note it in the spread sheet here. This should not include errors in the original block print, which we will leave as is, but there may have been an error in the text input of the eKangyur from the original scanned source. The source of the eKangyur is the scanned LoC edition on tbrc.org, W4CZ5369 (Although it follows the volume order of W22084, the Parphud edition on tbrc.org). Occasionally the print may be illegible due to smudges, and so you may compare with W22084, which as far as I know is nearly identical. Of course, it not really our job to proof read the eKangyur, so don't spend hours checking for typos in the eKangyur; but you may happen to notice an error now and then while checking the source, and in such case you can enter them into the spreadsheet and they can be reported to Esukhia at some point.
